column3: No evidence to support Foreign Minister Bob Carr's economic migrants claims
column4: Foreign Minister Bob Carr claims people arriving in Australia recently by boat are not refugees fleeing persecution, but economic migrants.
column17: Bob Carr says 100 per cent of recent boat arrivals are economic migrants, not refugees.
column18: Neither Senator Carr's office nor the Immigration Department has been able to produce evidence to support the claim.

column3: Tony Burke not telling the full story on unaccompanied asylum seeker children
column4: The Federal Government's refugee deal with Papua New Guinea sparked questions about who will be responsible for unaccompanied minors sent offshore.
column17: Tony Burke says he will ensure unaccompanied asylum seekers under the age of 18 have appropriate accommodation, services, and schooling in PNG
column18: Legally, Mr Burke is not responsible for the safety of children in Papua New Guinea.

column3: Tony Abbott's comments on same-sex marriage laws mostly true
column4: Some state governments have raised the prospect of introducing their own same-sex marriage laws. But Opposition Leader Tony Abbott claims marriage is a responsibility of the Commonwealth parliament.
column17: Tony Abbott says marriage is a responsibility of the Commonwealth parliament.
column18: The states can make laws allowing same-sex marriage, but it's unclear whether those laws would stand if challenged in the High Court.

column3: Julian Assange goes too far on Barack Obama's prosecutions against whistleblowers
column4: Julian Assange claims Barack Obama has prosecuted more whistleblowers for espionage than all previous US presidents combined since 1917.
column17: Julian Assange says Barack Obama has prosecuted more whistleblowers for espionage than all previous US presidents combined since 1917. He says the number was double.
column18: Seven whistleblowers have been prosecuted for espionage during Mr Obama's presidency. The number for all previous presidents since 1917 is six.

column3: Labor MP Michelle Rowland incorrect on the Coalition's policy costings
column4: Federal Labor member for Greenway in New South Wales, Michelle Rowland, claims the Coalition has not submitted any policies for costing to the Parliamentary Budget Office.
column17: Michelle Rowland says the Coalition has not submitted any policies for costing to the Parliamentary Budget Office.
column18: The Coalition has submitted more than 200 policies to the PBO.

column3: Kevin Rudd's ad on Australia's debt, credit rating checks out
column4: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd claims Australia's debt per capita is one of the lowest in the developed world, and Australia is one of only eight countries given a AAA credit rating with a stable outlook.
column17: The claims: Kevin Rudd says Australia's debt per capita is one of the lowest in the developed world, and Australia is one of only eight countries given a credit rating of AAA with a stable outlook.
column18: These claims are accurate.

column3: Kevin Rudd's $70 billion black hole claim not credible
column4: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd claims the Opposition would need to make $70 billion in cuts to match the Government's path to budget surplus.
column17: Kevin Rudd says the Opposition would have to make $70 billion in cuts to match the Government's path to budget surplus.
column18: The figure, based on Labor's estimate of the Coalition's budget costings, is not credible. It includes outdated spending plans and outdated revenue reductions.

column3: Kevin Rudd can defend his jobs claim but Tony Abbott is more on the money
column4: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd says 1 million jobs have been created over the past five and a half years. But Opposition Leader Tony Abbott Opposition claims unemployment is marching towards 800,000. Can they both be right?
column17: The claims: Kevin Rudd says 1 million jobs have been created over the past five and a half years. Tony Abbott says unemployment is marching towards 800,000.
column18: Both claims are correct, but Mr Abbott's better reflects the deteriorating job market.

column3: Tony Abbott correct on Pacific Solution outcome
column4: Opposition Leader Tony Abbott claims that during the Howard government's Pacific Solution, 40 per cent of the people sent to Manus Island and Nauru were permanently settled in Australia.
column17: Tony Abbott claims 40 per cent of the people sent to Manus Island and Nauru were permanently settled in Australia.
column18: His claim checks out.

column3: Kevin Rudd's claim that Labor has been a lower taxing government checks out
column4: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd claims that "under this government, the tax to GDP ratio has, in the period we've been in office, [been] an average of 22.7 per cent".

column3: Labor's National Broadband Network ad oversimplifies its benefits
column4: The Australian Labor Party has launched a political advertisement about its National Broadband Network (NBN) which makes claims on cost, speed and rollout.
column6: Not full story; not yet; true

column3: Joe Hockey exaggerates difference between Labor, Coalition record on debt
column4: Opposition Treasury spokesman Joe Hockey claims the Labor Government has taken on large amounts of debt while the previous Coalition government left the nation with more assets than debt.
column17: Joe Hockey says the Coalition left the country with net assets of $70 billion, whereas if it wins the election he says it will inherit debt going to $400 billion.
column18: Mr Hockey is making an exaggerated claim by conflating net and gross figures and ignoring the Coalition's contribution to gross debt.

column3: Tony Abbott wrong on child immunisation rates
column4: Opposition Leader Tony Abbott claims child immunisation rates have fallen under the Labor government.

column3: Bob Katter wrong on number of gun deaths after Port Arthur
column4: Katter's Australian Party leader Bob Katter claims gun-related deaths rose after the introduction of John Howard's National Firearms Agreement in 1996.
column17: Bob Katter claims there were more gun deaths after the 1996 gun laws were introduced than there were in the three years before.
column18: There were more deaths before the gun laws were introduced than there were in the three years after. Mr Katter is wrong.

column3: Kevin Rudd goes too far on paid parental leave for millionaires
column4: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd claims the Coalition's signature promise would unfairly pay thousands of dollars in parental leave to men who earn a million dollars a year.

column3: Kevin Rudd wrong on Tony Abbott's '$1b hospital funding cut'
column4: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd has accused Opposition Leader Tony Abbott of cutting $1 billion in public hospital funding when he was health minister.
column17: Kevin Rudd says when Tony Abbott was health minister he cut $1 billion from the public hospitals budget of Australia.
column18: Mr Abbott was not responsible for the $1 billion reduction in public hospital funding between 2003 and 2008.

column3: Kevin Rudd's parental leave, child care comparison incorrect
column4: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd says the Coalition's paid parental leave scheme costs $22 billion, which he claims is more than the Government spends on childcare support.
column17: Kevin Rudd says the Coalition's paid parental leave scheme costs $22 billion, which he says is more than the Government spends on childcare support.
column18: Incorrect. Childcare costs will outstrip the costs of the paid parental leave scheme by the time it begins on July 1, 2015.

column3: Clive Palmer wrong on infant mortality rates
column4: Federal MP and businessman Clive Palmer claims infant mortality rates are higher among Indigenous Australians than in Africa, Asia or South America.

column3: Tony Abbott's claim households will be $550 a year better off without the carbon tax is outdated
column4: Opposition Leader Tony Abbott says households will be $550 a year better off if the Coalition scraps the carbon tax.
column17: Tony Abbott says households will be $550 a year better off if the Coalition scraps the carbon tax.
column18: Mr Abbott's figure is outdated. It refers to a fixed price on carbon, which would cost an average household $568 in 2014-15, not Labor's proposed emissions trading scheme, which would cost $134.

column3: Kevin Rudd's high speed rail, parental leave cost comparison is unsound
column4: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd claims building a high speed rail project from Brisbane to Melbourne by 2035 would cost less than the Coalition's paid parental leave scheme for the same period of time.
column9: High Speed Rail vs Paid Parental Leave
column17: Kevin Rudd says building a high speed rail project from Brisbane to Melbourne by 2035 would cost less than the Coalition's paid parental leave scheme for the same period of time.
column18: Mr Rudd's claim is unsound. Given the uncertainties surrounding the cost of both schemes, it is premature to compare them at this time.

column3: Chris Bowen correct on investor impact of parental leave scheme
column4: Treasurer Chris Bowen claims the Coalition's proposed paid parental leave scheme will cost Australian investors $1.6 billion.
column17: Chris Bowen says the Coalition's proposed paid parental leave scheme will cost Australian investors $1.6 billion.
column18: Mr Bowen is correct. But the $1.6 billion in forgone franking credits will only hit investors in 2016-17.

column3: National Tertiary Education Union correct on university class sizes
column4: An advertisement by the National Tertiary Education Union claims there are almost twice as many university students per teacher now than there were a generation ago.
column17: The amount of university students in a one-teacher classroom has almost doubled since 1990.
column18: The claim is correct. There are almost twice as many students per teacher now than there were in the 1990s.

column3: Clive Palmer wrong on asylum seekers being paid more than pensioners
column4: Federal MP and businessman Clive Palmer claims Australia's senior citizens are paid less than newly arrived asylum seekers.
column17: Clive Palmer says senior citizens in Australia are paid less than newly arrived asylum seekers.
column18: Mr Palmer is wrong, and his explanation for the claim does not stack up.

column3: Greg Hunt not giving the full story on climate research
column4: Opposition Climate spokesman Greg Hunt claims CSIRO research shows carbon emissions can be reduced by 20 per cent over 40 years using nature, soils and trees.
column17: Greg Hunt says CSIRO research shows carbon emissions can be reduced by 20 per cent over 40 years using nature, soils and trees.
column18: Mr Hunt quotes the figure for potential abatement accurately, but he leaves out the uncertainties and practical challenges in a large body of research and articles published by its scientists.

column3: Penny Wong selective in jobs attack on Coalition
column4: Finance Minister Penny Wong claims there is a $2.4 billion hole in the Coalition's costing of its plan to shed 12,000 public service jobs.
column17: Penny Wong says there is a $2.4 billion hole in the Coalition's costing of its plan to shed 12,000 public service jobs.
column18: The Government has cherrypicked assumptions that would produce the best result in its favour.

column3: Labor Party ad overreaches on Coalition school funding cuts
column4: An education advertisement released by the Federal Government claims every school in Australia will be affected by cuts planned by Opposition Leader Tony Abbott.
column17: The Federal Government says every school in Australia will be affected by cuts planned by Opposition Leader Tony Abbott.
column18: For the Government to suggest there will be "bigger classes, less teachers, less support staff and less programs" is an overreach.

column3: Peter Dutton oversimplifies increase in elective surgery, GP waiting times
column4: Opposition health spokesman Peter Dutton claims that under the Labor Government, Australians are waiting longer to see their GP and waiting longer for elective surgery.
column17: Peter Dutton says people are waiting longer to see their GP and waiting longer for elective surgery around Australia.
column18: Mr Dutton's statement is oversimplified. Nationally, elective surgery median waiting times were higher in 2011-12 than 2007-8. But waiting times have fallen in some states. Similarly, while some people are waiting longer to see a GP, others experienced a decrease in waiting time.

column3: Oversimplified: '80,000 charity workers' would be affected by FBT changes
column4: Two industry associations claim tens of thousands of charity workers would be affected by Labor's proposed changes to the way Fringe Benefits Tax can be calculated for salary sacrificed cars.
column17: Two industry associations say 80,000 charity workers would be affected by Labor's proposed changes to the way Fringe Benefits Tax can be calculated for salary sacrificed cars.
column18: The claim is oversimplified. All charity workers driving a car and claiming any tax concession will be required to complete a log book. Charity workers will be affected, but it is impossible to say whether the financial impact will be adverse.

column3: Fact Check: Greens Senator Scott Ludlam exaggerates rent increases
column4: Greens Senator Scott Ludlam claims rental prices have doubled across the country and tripled in the ACT, Queensland and WA since 2000.
column17: Greens Senator Scott Ludlam says rental prices have doubled across the country and tripled in the ACT, Queensland and WA since 2000.
column18: In dollar figures, national rental rates have doubled since 2000 but they have not tripled. According to the real value of the dollar which takes inflation into account, rents have not doubled or tripled anywhere in Australia.

column3: Kevin Rudd takes car subsidy figures out of context
column4: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd says Australia's assistance to the car manufacturing industry is one of the lowest in the world. He claims car industry assistance is $18 per head per year in Australia, $90 in the United States and $96 in Germany.
column17: Kevin Rudd says car industry assistance is $18 per head per year in Australia, $90 in the United States and $96 in Germany.
column18: The subsidy of $18 per head per year for Australia is correct but the figures for the US and Germany are not "per year" figures.

column3: Kevin Rudd correct on Paul's references to slavery in the Bible
column4: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd claims St Paul said in the New Testament, 'slaves be obedient to your masters'.
column17: Kevin Rudd says St Paul said in the New Testament, 'slaves be obedient to your masters'.
column18: Mr Rudd is correct. There are two statements from Paul in the New Testament which call on slaves to be obedient to their masters. But the Bible does not present a single view on slavery.

column3: Scott Morrison correct on 'illegal entry' of people without a visa
column4: Opposition immigration spokesman Scott Morrison claims people illegally enter Australia when they arrive without a valid visa, and that the term 'illegal entry' is used in international conventions.
column17: Scott Morrison says people illegally enter Australia when they come without a valid visa and says the term 'illegal entry' is used in international conventions.
column18: Mr Morrison is correct. Based on the definition set out in the United Nations people smuggling protocol, people who have come to Australia without a valid visa have illegally entered the country. That is the case even though these people have not committed any crime, nor broken any Australian or international law.

column3: Christopher Pyne exaggerates trade training centre rollout figures
column4: Opposition education spokesman Christopher Pyne claims the Government has built only 230 trade training centres of the 2,650 promised by Kevin Rudd in 2007.
column17: Christopher Pyne says the Government has built only 230 trade training centres of the 2,650 promised by Kevin Rudd in 2007.
column18: The Government has built 302 trade training centres servicing 825 schools. Mr Pyne exaggerated the numbers to make his point about the slow pace of the roll-out.

column3: Christine Milne in the ballpark on cost of Coalition's Nauru tent city
column4: Greens leader Christine Milne claims the Coalition's 'tent city' on Nauru will cost $1.9 billion over four years.
column17: Christine Milne says the Coalition's 'tent city' on Nauru will cost $1.9 billion over four years.
column18: The publicly available economic information is insufficient to assess the cost of the Coalition's Nauru policy precisely. Senator Milne is in the ballpark to say 2,000 additional places will cost "something like $1.9 billion over the forward estimates".

column3: Threat to the survival of local pharmacies exaggerated
column4: The Pharmacy Guild of Australia claims that bringing forward reductions in the prices of prescription medicines will threaten the survival of local pharmacies.
column17: The Pharmacy Guild of Australia says bringing forward reductions in the prices of prescription medicines will threaten the survival of local pharmacies.
column18: The guild's claim is exaggerated. Pharmacies have been adjusting to a price-cutting regime since 2007 and there is little evidence to suggest the impact will be severe across the industry.

column3: Rupert Murdoch's public sector pay, sick leave tweet checks out
column4: News Corporation's executive chairman Rupert Murdoch claims public workers in Australia earn more and take many more sick days than their private sector counterparts.
column17: Rupert Murdoch says public workers in Australia earn more and take many more sick days than their private sector counterparts.
column18: Mr Murdoch's claim that public sector employees earn more and take more sick leave than their private sector counterparts checks out.

column3: Tim Costello's claim foreign aid cuts will cost 450,000 lives is not credible
column4: The Coalition's proposed $4.5 billion cuts to foreign aid will result in the loss of 450,000 lives, World Vision Australia chief executive officer Tim Costello claims.
column17: Tim Costello says the Coalition's proposed $4.5 billion cuts to foreign aid will result in the loss of 450,000 lives.
column18: Mr Costello's claim is not credible.

column3: Clive Palmer's economic stimulus claim improbable
column4: Federal MP and businessman Clive Palmer claims the economy would be better off if Australian companies were not forced to pay tax in instalments.
column17: Clive Palmer says the economy would be better off if Australian companies were not forced to pay tax in instalments.
column18: Mr Palmer's claim is improbable. Economic theory and historical data show the tax change would do little to stimulate the economy.

column3: Syrian president Bashar al-Assad's sarin gas claim implausible
column4: Syrian president Bashar al-Assad claims sarin is a primitive gas that can be made in a backyard, and could have been used by rebels in the suspected chemical attack in Damascus on August 2013.
column17: Syrian president Bashar al-Assad says sarin is a primitive gas that can be made in a backyard, and could have been used by rebels in the suspected chemical attack in Damascus on August 21.
column18: There is significant evidence and intelligence linking the Assad regime to the attack. Intelligence agencies and NGOs have found no evidence that any group other than the Assad government possesses chemical weapons on a scale deployed on August 21 or the types of rockets involved.

column3: Julia Gillard's 'carbon tax' regrets debatable
column4: Julia Gillard claims her decision not to argue against a fixed carbon price being labelled a "tax" hurt her politically.
column17: Julia Gillard says her decision not to argue against a fixed carbon price being labelled a "carbon tax" hurt her terribly politically.
column18: Ms Gillard had strong grounds to argue the carbon price was not legally a tax, but she would have faced credible counter-arguments to the contrary.

column3: Ita Buttrose correct: Glass ceiling still exists in Australia
column4: Australian of the Year Ita Buttrose claims the lack of women in Prime Minister Tony Abbott's cabinet shows the glass ceiling still exists in Australia and that women are yet to break through it.
column17: Ita Buttrose says the lack of women in Tony Abbott's cabinet shows women are yet to break through the glass ceiling.
column18: When the glass ceiling is measured in terms of the under-representation of women in senior levels of Australian politics and business, and persistent income inequality, Ms Buttrose is correct.

column3: Greens Senator Rachel Siewert's foreign ownership claim overstated
column4: Greens Senator Rachel Siewert claims China and the US would not allow a foreign government to buy 1 million hectares of land.
column17: Rachel Siewert says China and the US would not allow a foreign government to buy 1 million hectares of land.
column18: Senator Siewert's claim is overstated. In China, foreign governments cannot buy large parcels of agricultural land. But in the some parts of the United States, foreign governments can purchase large parcels of agricultural land if the acquisition is not a threat national security.

column3: Rudd, Abbott, Palmer's ad spending claims pure campaign spin
column4: ALP leader Kevin Rudd, Coalition leader Tony Abbott and Palmer United Party leader Clive Palmer all accuse each other of attempting to win the election with massive spending on advertising. Are their claims correct?
column5: Kevin Rudd, Tony Abbott, Clive Palmer
column17: Labor said the Coalition was spending 10 times as much on negative ads, the Coalition said Labor would massively outspend it and Clive Palmer said the Liberals spent $54 million on their campaign.
column18: On current information, Mr Rudd, Mr Abbott and Mr Palmer's election campaign spending claims are nothing more than campaign rhetoric.

column3: Concern Australian bank lending 'exceptionally high' is overblown
column4: Investment strategist Paul Schulte claims Australian banks are lending too much money.
column17: Investment strategist Paul Schulte says Australian banks are lending too much money.
column18: While Mr Schulte's claim that Australia's loan-to-deposit ratio is high checks out, it doesn't take into account the stable nature of Australia's banking system and the fact that our loan-to-deposit ratio is getting better. The claim is overblown.

column3: Are the big chains' discount vouchers forcing small petrol stations out of business?
column4: Newspaper advertisements placed by Independent retailers claim unsubsidised petrol stations cannot compete if discounts offered by supermarket chains go above 6 or 7 cents per litre.
column17: Independent retailers say unsubsidised petrol stations cannot compete if discounts offered by supermarket chains go above 6 or 7 cents per litre.
column18: The claim is not the full story. Prolonged discounting at higher levels could force some service stations into losses on their petrol products business. But their viability could depend on their ability to mitigate these losses from their sales of non-petrol products.

column3: Is it illegal to turn back boats in international waters to Indonesia?
column4: Indonesian politician Tantowi Yahya claims it is illegal for Australia to turn back asylum seeker boats in international waters.
column17: Indonesian politician Tantowi Yahya says it is illegal for Australia to turn back asylum seeker boats in international waters.
column18: Mr Yahya's statement is correct, but there is more to the story. The Government cannot legally turn back boats in international waters. But the Government can legally turn back asylum seeker boats intercepted within 24 nautical miles of the Australian coastline, provided it is safe to do so.

column3: Will New South Wales run short of gas by 2016?
column4: Federal Industry Minister Ian Macfarlane claims gas supply problems are looming in NSW because there has been insufficient progress in developing its coal seam gas industry.
column17: Federal Industry Minister Ian Macfarlane says gas supply problems are looming in NSW because there has been insufficient progress in developing its coal seam gas industry.
column18: Mr Macfarlane's claim is unverifiable.

column3: AFL the big winner from decade of investment in sporting infrastructure
column4: Former Victorian premier and president of AFL club Hawthorn, Jeff Kennett, claims AFL CEO Andrew Demetriou secured hundreds of millions of dollars for ground upgrades, giving the game supremacy over other codes.
column17: Jeff Kennett says Andrew Demetriou has used his 10 years in the top job to secure hundreds of millions of dollars from governments for AFL ground upgrades, which has put the code on the top of the heap.
column18: Mr Kennett is correct when he says hundreds of millions of dollars in government money has been invested under Mr Demetriou's watch.

column3: What Greg Hunt didn't say about the carbon price and emissions
column4: New federal Environment Minister Greg Hunt claims emissions increased from 560 to 637 million tonnes under the carbon price.
column17: Greg Hunt says emissions went up under the carbon price from 560 to 637 million tonnes.
column18: Mr Hunt based his claim on modelling for the year 2020. He failed to mention that the same modelling projects that emissions would go up further if a carbon price wasn't in place. Mr Hunt's claim is misleading.

column3: Do Australians waste $8 billion worth of edible food each year?
column4: FoodWise, a national campaign run by not-for-profit group DoSomething, says Australians throw out $8 billion worth of edible food every year.
column17: The FoodWise campaign says Australians throw out $8 billion worth of edible food every year.
column18: Based on the available research, the claim stacks up. But the $8 billion only relates to household food waste. The total value of food waste in Australia would far exceed this figure.

column3: Christopher Pyne exaggerates Labor's international student 'failure'
column4: Federal Education Minister, Christopher Pyne claims since 2008 Labor has shrunk the international student industry by about a quarter.
column17: Christopher Pyne says since 2008 Labor has shrunk the international student industry by about a quarter.
column18: Mr Pyne overstates how far the international student industry has shrunk and his claim that Labor was responsible for the drop is not the full story.

column3: Abbott splitting hairs on the difference between towing and turning back the boats
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims there is a big between turning boats around in Australian waters and the Australian Navy towing them back to Indonesia.
column17: Tony Abbott says there is a world of difference between turning boats around in Australian waters and the Australian Navy towing them back to Indonesia.
column18: In practical terms, "turn back" and "tow back" are interchangeable depending on the circumstances. Mr Abbott is splitting hairs.

column3: Greens' claims over Ferguson lobbying are in the ballpark
column4: Australian Greens' leader Christine Milne says former federal resources and energy minister Martin Ferguson's new jobs as group executive of natural resources for Seven Group Holdings and as chair to a petroleum industry advisory board, make a mockery of the lobbying code of conduct.
column17: Christine Milne says former resources minister Martin Ferguson's new jobs make a mockery of the lobbying code of conduct.
column18: By taking up the appointment within the cooling off period it can be argued that Mr Ferguson has made a mockery of the intent and spirit of the code.

column3: Doing the sums: How much is Clive Palmer worth?
column4: Federal MP and businessman Clive Palmer is referred to as a billionaire in the media, but he claims: "I don't say I'm a billionaire. I've never said that. I've never said I've got any money".
column17: Clive Palmer is constantly referred to as a billionaire in the media, but the man himself has been vague on the details of his wealth.
column18: Based on publicly available information, as at June 30, 2012, Mr Palmer's wealth is $1.13 billion.

column3: MP expenses: Are the rules clear?
column4: Labor leadership contender Anthony Albanese claims the rules on MP entitlements are "pretty clear".
column17: Anthony Albanese says the rules on MP entitlements are "pretty clear".
column18: The rules are not clear. In the many documents describing how the system works, there is no definition of what constitutes parliamentary, electorate and official business.

column3: Financial advisers not telling the full story on superannuation property risks
column4: The head of a self-managed superannuation fund claims there is no evidence that self-managed super funds make reckless residential property purchases.
column17: Andrea Slattery says there is no evidence self-managed super funds are making reckless residential property purchases.
column18: Ms Slattery's claim is not the full story. Ms Slattery is right that residential property represents a small 3 per cent of all SMSF assets. However, when commercial property is added, the figure is 15 per cent and growing.

column3: Can Australia become the world's leading LNG exporter?
column4: Industry Minister Ian Macfarlane claims Australia is set to become the world's second largest or largest exporter of LNG.
column17: Industry Minister Ian Macfarlane says Australia is set to become the world's second largest or largest exporter of LNG.
column18: Mr Macfarlane's prediction is soundly based on official research. But its fulfilment could be undermined by factors such as planned expansion in the US and Canada, or domestic issues such as increasing labour costs.

column3: Will the ACT's marriage equality bill survive a High Court challenge?
column4: ACT Chief Minister Katy Gallagher claims the ACT's marriage equality laws can operate concurrently with the federal Marriage Act.
column17: Katy Gallagher says the ACT's marriage equality laws can operate concurrently with the federal Marriage Act.
column18: The ACT bill has some problems and its long-term prospects for success are doubtful.

column3: Do vegetarians weigh less and have lower risk of disease than meat-eaters?
column4: Animal rights group PETA claims vegetarians and vegans weigh less than meat eaters and have a reduced risk of diseases such as cancer, heart disease, diabetes and strokes.
column17: Animal rights group PETA says vegetarians and vegans weigh less than meat eaters and have a reduced risk of diseases such as cancer, heart disease, diabetes and strokes.
column18: PETA's claim is correct, but there's more to the story. A poorly planned vegetarian/vegan diet can result in nutritional deficiencies and other health problems, and it is misleading to suggest an absence of meat alone will bring about weight loss.

column3: Would a delay in ACT same-sex marriage avoid leaving couples in limbo?
column4: Federal Attorney-General George Brandis has asked the ACT Government not to give effect to its new laws until their constitutional validity is determined by the High Court.
column17: George Brandis has asked the ACT not to give effect to its new same-sex marriage laws until their constitutional validity is determined by the High Court.
column18: It's a fair bet that the ACT can take up the Federal Government's suggestion to delay the start of the marriage equality laws until the High Court makes a decision.

column3: Coalition in the ballpark on household savings from axing the carbon tax
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott and Environment Minister Greg Hunt claim axing the carbon price will save households an average of $550 next financial year.
column17: Tony Abbott and Greg Hunt say axing the carbon price will save households an average of $550 next financial year.
column18: In the 2014-15 financial year, households will be better off to the tune of $550 than they would be if current legislation stayed in force. The following year, when the legislation introduces a floating price, the estimated impact on households would halve to $280.

column3: Are train drivers in the Pilbara the highest paid in the world?
column4: UK transport commentator, Christian Wolmar claims train drivers in the Pilbara earn about $240,000 a year and are probably the highest-paid train drivers in the world.
column17: A UK transport commentator says train drivers in the Pilbara earn about $240,000 a year and are probably the highest-paid in the world
column18: The Pilbara has the highest number of best paid train drivers in Australia. Some drivers in the region earn $240,000. Given the unique conditions in the Pilbara and Australia's high salary ranking in the resources and mining industry, it's likely these drivers are among the highest paid in the world.

column3: Palmer United Party unlikely to get same number of staff as the Greens
column4: Federal MP and businessman Clive Palmer claims he will ask the Prime Minister for the same level of resources as the Greens had in the last government.
column17: Clive Palmer says he will ask the Prime Minister for the same level of resources as the Greens had in the last government.
column18: When the Greens held the balance of power in the Senate, they negotiated 18 extra staff. With only three senators, it is unlikely Mr Palmer would be given that many extra staff.

column3: Has hazard reduction in NSW increased two-and-a-half times under Barry O'Farrell?
column4: NSW Premier Barry O'Farrell claims his government has increased the amount of hazard reduction two-and-a-half times.
column17: NSW Premier Barry O'Farrell says his Government has increased the amount of hazard reduction two-and-a-half times.
column18: A full two-and-a-half times increase would have seen 294,083 hectares completed in 2012-2013, not 281,492. And under the previous Labor government, a significantly larger amount of hazard reduction work was completed than in either 2010-2011 or 2011-12 under Mr O'Farrell. Mr O'Farrell's claim is close to the mark.

column3: Tanya Plibersek wrong on the history of women in cabinet
column4: Deputy Opposition Leader Tanya Plibersek claims the last time there was only one woman in Cabinet was 1976.
column17: Tanya Plibersek says the last time there was only one woman in Cabinet was 1976.
column18: The last time only one woman was in cabinet was in 2001. Ms Plibersek is wrong.

column3: Barnaby Joyce correct on bird flu risk in free-range chicken farms
column4: Federal Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce claims a move towards free-range egg production will lead to an increase in bird flu.
column17: Barnaby Joyce says a move towards free-range egg production will lead to an increase in bird flu.
column18: It is almost impossible to stop free-range chickens from coming into contact with avian influenza when they leave the shed. It is easier to prevent caged hens from contracting the virus. Mr Joyce's claim is correct.

column3: Will abolishing the carbon tax reduce power bills?
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims electricity and gas prices will drop by 9 per cent and 7 per cent once the carbon tax is abolished.
column17: Tony Abbott says electricity and gas prices will drop by 9 per cent and 7 per cent once the carbon tax is abolished.
column18: It is impossible to predict with precision. Many factors determine electricity and gas prices other than the carbon tax.

column3: Joe Hockey's Australia, US debt ceiling comparison overblown
column4: Federal Treasurer Joe Hockey claims raising Australia's debt ceiling from $300 billion to $500 billion will prevent a US-style crisis.
column17: Joe Hockey says raising Australia's debt ceiling from $300 billion to $500 billion will prevent a US-style crisis.
column18: Given the fundamental differences in the two political systems, the "tremendous uncertainty" experienced in the US debt crisis would not be mirrored in Australia.

column3: Tony Abbott incorrect on the history of marriage
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims marriage, or marriage-like relationships, have always been between a man and a woman
column17: Tony Abbott says marriage, or marriage-like relationships, have always been between a man and a woman
column18: A significant body of academic work shows that marriage and "other solemnised relationships" have not always been between "a man and a woman".

column3: On the money: Mathias Cormann says Medibank Private sale will not raise premiums
column4: Finance Minister Mathias Cormann claims privatising Medibank Private won't cause premiums to increase.
column17: Finance Minister Mathias Cormann says privatising Medibank Private won't cause premiums to increase.
column18: Medibank Private already operates like a commercial business, and does not lead on price. Senator Cormann is on the money.

column3: Christopher Pyne in the red on student outcomes in independent public schools
column4: Federal Education Minister Christopher Pyne claims independent public schools are improving student outcomes in Western Australia.
column17: Christopher Pyne says independent public schools are improving student outcomes in Western Australia.
column18: There has been no measured improvement in student outcomes in WA's independent public schools. Mr Pyne's claims are unsubstantiated.

column3: Are Queensland's new bikie laws too harsh to survive in other states and territories?
column4: Former NSW public prosecutor Nicholas Cowdery claims Queensland's tough new bikie legislation would be "totally impossible" to pass in the ACT and Victoria, where human rights charters are in place.
column17: Former NSW public prosecutor Nicholas Cowdery says Queensland's tough new bikie legislation would be "totally impossible" to pass in the ACT and Victoria, where human rights charters are in place.
column18: The human rights charters in the ACT and Victoria cannot stop other laws from coming into force. While they may lead to greater scrutiny of Queensland-like bikie legislation, it would not be "totally impossible" for the legislation to pass into law.

column3: Would losing the car industry cost more than maintaining it, as Kim Carr claims?
column4: Opposition Industry Minister Kim Carr claims economic modelling shows it would cost more money to lose the car industry than it would to subsidise it.
column17: Kim Carr says economic modelling shows it would cost more money to lose the car industry than it would to subsidise it.
column18: It is difficult to predict with any certainty today whether losing the industry would really cost the economy more money than paying subsidies to maintain it.

column3: Rupert Murdoch's vision for Australian diversity checks out
column4: News Corp executive chairman Rupert Murdoch claims Australia is on its way to becoming what may be the world's most diverse nation.
column17: Mr Murdoch says Australia is on its way to becoming what may be the world's most diverse nation.
column18: When diversity is measured in terms of migrants as a percentage of the total population, Mr Murdoch's claim checks out.

column3: Warren Truss inflates the impact of GrainCorp's sale on ports
column4: Deputy Prime Minister Warren Truss claims if the sale of GrainCorp proceeds international companies will control Australia's ports and handling facilities, and decisions will be made in foreign boardrooms.
column17: Warren Truss says if the sale of GrainCorp proceeds international companies will control Australia's ports and handling facilities, and decisions will be made in foreign boardrooms.
column18: If the deal goes ahead the majority of wheat export ports and the handling supply chain will be in foreign hands. Presumably most big decisions for these companies will be made in foreign boardrooms, however some operational decisions will made by Australian-based management.

column3: Does the Abbott Government have a mandate to overturn the carbon tax?
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims the Opposition must respect the Government's mandate to overturn the carbon tax.
column17: Tony Abbott says the Opposition must respect the Government's mandate to overturn the carbon tax.
column18: There is no enforceable obligation for any party to support the policy position of its opponent simply because that opponent won the power to govern.

column3: Is it cheaper for MPs to fly VIP jets, as Christopher Pyne claims?
column4: Government frontbencher Christopher Pyne claims a VIP Boeing business jet flight from Perth to Canberra taken by a group of WA Liberal MPs was probably cheaper than a commercial flight
column17: Christopher Pyne says a VIP Boeing business jet flight from Perth to Canberra taken by a group of WA Liberal MPs was probably cheaper than a commercial flight.
column18: Commercial fares would have cost a maximum of $56,260 whereas the cost of sending the VIP jet to Perth would have been a minimum of $140,483.

column3: CSIRO job cuts: Greens MP Adam Bandt turns to spin
column4: Greens MP Adam Bandt claims a recruitment freeze at the CSIRO is part of the Abbott Government's anti-science bias and that a quarter of jobs could be lost within a year.
column17: Adam Bandt says a recruitment freeze at the CSIRO is part of the Abbott Government's anti-science bias and that a quarter of jobs could be lost within a year.
column18: A quarter of jobs at the CSIRO cannot be lost within a year and Mr Bandt did not substantiate his claim that the Government is behind the jobs freeze.

column3: Proceeds of crime: Do NSW police seize more than the rest of Australia?
column4: New South Wales Premier Barry O'Farrell claims NSW collects more from proceeds of crime than all other states and the federal government combined.
column17: Barry O'Farrell says NSW collects more from proceeds of crime than all other states and the federal government combined.
column18: Mr O'Farrell's claim is based on old data. The total proceeds of crime in all other states and the Commonwealth was greater than that of NSW from 2005-2006 to 2012-13.

column3: Does Indonesia have to take asylum seekers rescued by the Australian Navy?
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims that under "normal international law", if asylum seeker boats are rescued in a country's search and rescue zone, that country has an obligation to take them.
column17: Tony Abbott says "normal international law" is that if asylum seeker boats are rescued in a country's search and rescue zone, that country has an obligation to take them.
column18: Mr Abbott goes a step too far when he says that Indonesia is obliged to take in people just because they are rescued in its search and rescue region.

column3: Chris Bowen wrong on Government's decision to scrap self-education expenses cap
column4: Opposition treasury spokesman Chris Bowen claims the Government's decision to scrap a $2,000 cap on self-education expenses will allow people to travel as much as they like and claim as much as they like.
column17: Chris Bowen says the Government's decision to scrap a $2,000 cap on self-education expenses will allow people to travel as much as they like and claim as much as they like.
column18: There are limits on what people can claim. A cap would have affected people undertaking local courses as well as those travelling overseas to study.

column3: Child poverty on the rise? ACOSS CEO Cassandra Goldie's claim is overblown
column4: Australian Council of Social Service CEO Cassandra Goldie claims child poverty is rising in Australia.
column17: ACOSS CEO Cassandra Goldie says child poverty is rising in Australia.
column18: The claim does not stack up. Leading research in the field shows child poverty has stayed stable over the last 10 years, with some bounces along the way.

column3: Is it illegal to spy on Indonesian officials, as president Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono claims?
column4: Indonesian president Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono claims it is illegal to tap the phones of officials of other countries under Indonesian, Australian and international law.
column17: Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono says it is illegal to tap the phones of officials of other countries under Indonesian, Australian and international law.
column18: Mr Yudhoyono goes too far when he describes spying's legal status in absolute terms.

column3: Clive Palmer incorrect on the number of executions in China
column4: Federal MP and businessman Clive Palmer claims the Chinese government executes 500,000 people a year.
column9: Palmer United Party, Human Rights, China
column17: Clive Palmer says the Chinese government executes 500,000 people a year.
column18: While the number of executions in China is a state secret, credible estimates put it between 3,000 and 5,000 in 2012. There is no evidence to support Mr Palmer's claim.

column3: Immigration Minister Scott Morrison not telling the full story on asylum seeker arrivals
column4: Immigration Minister Scott Morrison claims the Coalition's border protection policy has resulted in an 80 per cent reduction in asylum seekers arriving in Australia by boat.
column17: Scott Morrison says the Coalition's border protection policy has resulted in an 80 per cent reduction in asylum seekers arriving in Australia by boat.
column18: There has been an 80 per cent reduction. However, the reduction is part of an earlier trend which began under the former government.

column3: Would spying on East Timor by the Australian Secret Intelligence Service be illegal?
column4: Australian lawyer Bernard Collaery claims the head of ASIS ordered a team into East Timor to conduct work which was outside the proper functions of ASIS.
column17: Bernard Collaery says the head of ASIS ordered a team into East Timor to conduct work which was well outside the proper functions of ASIS.
column18: Mr Collaery is unlikely to be correct.

column3: Can a lower GST threshold for online purchases be achieved in Australia?
column4: NSW Treasurer Mike Baird claims other countries like the UK and Canada have lower GST thresholds for online shopping and that these thresholds can also be achieved in Australia.
column17: Mike Baird says other countries like the UK and Canada have lower GST thresholds for online shopping and that these thresholds can also be achieved in Australia.
column18: Mr Baird is correct in saying the UK and Canada have low thresholds, but whether something similar can be achieved here is uncertain.

column3: Impossible to guarantee no school will be worse off under Coalition funding arrangements
column4: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims the Coalition has broken its election promise that no school will be worse off than it would have been under Labor's Gonski funding plans.
column17: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten says the Coalition has broken its election promise that no school will be worse off than it would have been under Labor's Gonski funding plans.
column18: Under the new arrangements it is impossible for the Commonwealth to guarantee no school will be worse off. Mr Shorten is correct.

column3: Has plain tobacco packaging failed to stop people smoking?
column4: Tobacco company Philip Morris claims "the data is clear" that plain packaging has not stopped people smoking.
column17: Philip Morris says "the data is clear" that plain packaging has not stopped people smoking.
column18: The data commissioned by Philip Morris is not clear, it is inconclusive. And there is contrary evidence emerging to suggest plain packaging has had an impact.

column3: Auction clearance rates in Sydney, Melbourne based on incomplete data
column4: Financial analyst Mark Bayley claims auction clearance rates in Sydney are not transparent, real or representative of the actual rate at which houses are being sold.
column17: Financial analyst Mark Bayley says auction clearance rates in Sydney are not transparent, real or representative of the actual rate at which houses are being sold.
column18: Mr Bayley's claim checks out.

column3: Nick Xenophon not telling the full story on price of Australian cars overseas
column4: Independent Senator Nick Xenophon claims a Ford Territory that sells for $38,000 to $40,000 in Australia costs over $100,000 in Thailand.
column17: Nick Xenophon says a Ford Territory that retails for $38,000 to $40,000 in Australia costs over $100,000 in Thailand.
column18: Senator Xenophon's claim is not the full story. Excise is levied on all cars in Thailand, locally made or imported.

column3: Can governments protect people from killer sharks?
column4: WA Minister Troy Buswell claims implementing a series of measures to increase safety for swimmers and surfers in Western Australia "does not represent what you would call a culling" of sharks.
column17: Troy Buswell says new shark control measures in Western Australia do not represent a cull.
column18: The shark control strategy announced by the WA Government amounts to a cull. Evidence suggests drumlines reduce shark attacks, but Mr Buswell downplays the impact on sharks and other marine life.

column3: Was Labor's childcare fund only ever about the union?
column4: Assistant Minister for Education Sussan Ley claims Labor's $300 million fund to subsidise childcare workers' wages was only ever about the unions.
column17: Sussan Ley says Labor's $300 million fund to subsidise childcare workers' wages was only ever about the unions.
column18: Ms Ley's claim is in the ballpark. The fund distribution process favoured the union.

column3: Clive Palmer's billionaire status no longer certain
column4: Clive Palmer is often referred to as a billionaire, but is he?
column17: Clive Palmer is often referred to as a billionaire, but is he?
column18: It can no longer be demonstrated by publicly available data that Mr Palmer is a billionaire.

column3: Tony Abbott incorrect on asylum seekers breaking Australian law
column4: Tony Abbott claims asylum seekers who come to Australia are attempting to break Australian law.
column17: Tony Abbott says asylum seekers who come to Australia are attempting to break Australian law.
column18: Mr Abbott is incorrect. Australia recognises people's right to seek asylum and entering Australia without a valid visa is not a criminal offence.

column3: Is Australia's welfare spending heading down the same path as Europe's?
column4: Kevin Andrews has labelled Australia's welfare system unsustainable, saying that in 10 to 15 years' time Australia could find itself in the same situation as some European countries.
column17: Kevin Andrews has labelled Australia's welfare system unsustainable and says in 10 to 15 years' time Australia could find itself in the same situation that some European countries are in.
column18: Treasury projections to 2050 show welfare spending as a proportion of GDP will remain steady over the next three decades.

column3: Mandatory sentencing: does it reduce crime?
column4: NSW Bar Association president Phillip Boulten SC claims there is no evidence that mandatory sentencing decreases crime.
column17: Phillip Boulten says there is no evidence that mandatory sentencing ever decreases crime levels.
column18: The evidence for mandatory sentencing is contradictory, but there is some evidence to suggest that mandatory sentencing reduces the level of crime being committed.

column3: How fast are wages, productivity really growing in Australia?
column4: The president of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Ged Kearney, claims wages in Australia have been at their lowest rate of growth in decades and labour productivity is the highest it's been in decades.
column17: Ged Kearney says wages in Australia have been at their lowest rate of growth in decades and labour productivity is the highest it's been in decades.
column18: Wages growth is at low levels compared to recent years, however labour productivity is not at historically high levels.

column3: Is marijuana less dangerous than alcohol, as Barack Obama claims?
column4: Barack Obama claims smoking marijuana is less dangerous for health than drinking alcohol.
column17: Barack Obama says smoking marijuana is less dangerous than drinking alcohol.
column18: There is not enough evidence to substantiate Mr Obama's claim.

column3: Bill Shorten's car subsidy numbers irrelevant, outdated
column4: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims the level of subsides provided to car makers in Australia is lower than in other countries.
column17: Bill Shorten says the level of subsides provided to car makers in Australia is lower than in other countries.
column18: Mr Shorten's claim is based on outdated numbers that are irrelevant to the current debate.

column3: Malcolm Turnbull correct: Australian farmers among world's least subsidised
column4: Communications Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims Australian farmers are among the least subsidised in the world.
column17: Malcolm Turnbull says Australian farmers are among the least subsidised in the world.
column18: Australian farmers receive subsidies of 3 per cent, ranking them the second lowest in the OECD.

column3: Brendan O'Connor incorrect on Cole royal commission cost
column4: Opposition employment and workplace relations spokesman Brendan O'Connor claims the 2001 Building and Construction Industry Royal Commission cost $66 million, equating to $100 million in today's dollars.
column17: Opposition workplace relations spokesman Brendan O'Connor says the 2001 Building and Construction Industry Royal Commission cost $66 million, equating to $100 million in today's dollars.
column18: There is no evidence to support Mr O'Connor's claim. The official cost of the royal commission was $58.61 million, which equates to just under $80 million in today's terms.

column3: Bill Shorten cherrypicking manufacturing job loss figures
column4: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims a thousand manufacturing jobs have been lost every month the Abbott Government's been in power.
column17: Bill Shorten says a thousand manufacturing jobs have been lost every month the Abbott Government's been in power.
column18: Mr Shorten is talking about future job losses, which are not yet reflected in any official data. Moreover, ABS data clearly shows the number of people employed in manufacturing has been declining for decades, including under the former Labor government.

column3: Liberal MP Kelly O'Dwyer incorrect on Australia's refugee intake
column4: Liberal MP Kelly O'Dwyer claims Australia has one of the highest per capita refugee intakes in the world.
column17: Kelly O'Dwyer says Australia has one of the highest per capita refugee intakes in the world.
column18: Ms O'Dwyer is incorrect. She has only counted refugees resettled through the UN humanitarian program, not the combined figure that includes refugees recognised in Australia.

column3: Jobs and unemployment: What's the real story in Tasmania?
column4: Tasmanian permier Lara Giddings says 3,300 new jobs were created in the past six months. But opposition leader Will Hodgman claims 10,000 full-time jobs have been lost under the Labor-Green minority Government. Who is right?

column3: Is Australia responsible for asylum seekers detained on Manus Island?
column4: The president of the Australian Human Rights Commission, Gillian Triggs, claims asylum seekers in the Manus Island detention centre are Australia's responsibility.
column17: Gillian Triggs says asylum seekers in the Manus Island detention centre are Australia's primary responsibility.
column18: Under international law, Australia and Papua New Guinea both have responsibilities for the asylum seekers.

column3: Did the SA economy go backwards last year?
column4: South Australian Liberal Opposition Leader Steven Marshall claims the state's economy contracted in 2012-2013. But Premier Jay Weatherill claims the state's economy grew in the year to November. Who was right?

column3: How severe is the drought in Queensland and New South Wales?
column4: Tony Abbott claims some places in Queensland and NSW are experiencing a "once-in-a-quarter-century" or even a "once-in-a-century" drought.
column17: Tony Abbott says some places in Queensland and NSW are experiencing a "once-in-a-quarter-century" or even a "once-in-a-century" drought.
column18: The combination of low rainfall and high temperatures has created the most severe drought conditions in parts of Queensland and NSW ever recorded. Mr Abbott's claim checks out.

column3: Anthony Albanese wrong on government ownership of world's top airlines
column4: Opposition transport spokesman Anthony Albanese claims eight out of the world's top 10 airlines are majority government-owned.
column17: Anthony Albanese says eight out of the world's top 10 airlines are majority government-owned.
column18: None of the top 10 rankings of airlines based on passenger traffic, capacity, financial results, fleet size, employee numbers and customer feedback consistently include a majority of government-owned airlines. Mr Albanese is wrong.

column3: Joe Hockey correct on Australia's debt, spending
column4: Treasurer Joe Hockey claims the previous Labor government left Australia with the fastest growth in spending and the third highest growth in debt among 17 top surveyed countries by the International Monetary Fund.
column17: Joe Hockey says Australia has the fastest growth in spending and third highest growth in debt among 17 countries surveyed by the International Monetary Fund.
column18: Mr Hockey's comments on growth in spending and debt compared check out, although he fails to mention the fact that Australia's overall debt as a proportion of GDP remains at comparatively low levels.

column3: More to the story on Nova Peris's claim about the NT's banned drinker register
column4: Labor Party Senator Nova Peris claims alcohol-related emergency department admissions in Northern Territory hospitals increased by 80 per cent in the 14 months after the banned drinker register was scrapped.
column17: Nova Peris says alcohol-related emergency department admissions in Northern Territory hospitals increased by 80 per cent in the 14 months after the banned drinker register was scrapped.
column18: Alcohol-related emergency admissions to NT hospitals did increase by 80 per cent after the register was scrapped. However, they did not decrease while the register was in place and the upward spike began before it was removed.

column3: Tony Abbott not telling the full story on Alcoa and the carbon tax
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims the carbon tax is partly to blame for the closure of Alcoa's Point Henry aluminium smelter.

column3: Hillary Clinton's comparison of Vladimir Putin and Adolf Hitler checks out
column4: US secretary of state Hillary Clinton says claims made by Russian president Vladimir Putin to justify taking over Crimea are reminiscent of claims made by Adolf Hitler in the 1930s.
column17: Hillary Clinton says claims made by Russian president Vladimir Putin to justify taking over Crimea are reminiscent of claims made by Adolf Hitler in the 1930s.
column18: There are enough similarities between the actions of Germany prior to World War II and Mr Putin's Russia today to justify Ms Clinton's statement.

column3: How many people in the world watch the Australian Formula One Grand Prix?
column4: Victorian Premier Denis Napthine claims 450 million people around the world watch the Formula One Grand Prix in Melbourne.
column17: Denis Napthine says 450 million people around the world watch the Formula One Grand Prix in Melbourne.
column18: The 450 million figure refers to the audience of all Grand Prix races for 2013. Based on the available data, live audiences for the Australian Grand Prix fall somewhere between 20 million and 50 million.

column3: Will the budget be $13.8 billion better off if the mining tax is scrapped?
column4: Finance Minister Mathias Cormann claims scrapping the mining tax would improve the budget position by $13.8 billion.
column17: Mathias Cormann says scrapping the mining tax would improve the budget position by $13.8 billion.
column18: The $13.8 billion figure is not from scrapping the mining tax alone. It includes abolishing eight  spending measures, the largest of which was never associated with the mining tax. Senator Cormann's claim is exaggerated.

column3: Children in detention: Is Australia breaching international law?
column4: The president of the Human Rights Commission, Gillian Triggs, claims that under international law, children should not be detained for longer than absolutely necessary for health and security checks.
column9: Human Rights, international law, asylum seekers
column17: Gillian Triggs says under international law, children should not be detained for longer than absolutely necessary for health and security checks.
column18: Experts agree with Professor Triggs, and UN treaties also make it clear that children should not be placed in detention for any length of time.

column3: Tony Abbott's Tasmanian wilderness claim doesn't check out
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims the 74,000 hectares the Government is proposing to remove from the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area is not pristine forest.
column17: Tony Abbott says the 74,000 hectares the Government is proposing to remove from the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area is not pristine.
column18: Expert analysis suggests more than 85 per cent of the area has not been logged, and that there is only a small amount of degradation or plantation timber. Further, UNESCO does not require an area to be "pristine" in order to be listed as a World Heritage Area.

column3: Bill Shorten on WA education cuts: Doesn't check out
column4: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten says Tony Abbott and Christopher Pyne are to blame for WA's Barnett Government cutting $183 million claims education and axing 360 teachers and 350 teachers' aides and support staff.
column17: Bill Shorten says Tony Abbott and Christopher Pyne are to blame for WA's Barnett Government cutting $183 million from education and culling 360 teachers and 350 teachers' aides and support staff.
column18: The WA education budget increased by $300 million this year. WA hasn't signed any agreement that would allow the Federal Government to stop it cutting its own education budgets, so Mr Abbott and Mr Pyne have no control over the Barnett Government's education funding decisions.

column3: Global competitiveness, government regulation and productivity growth: Where does Australia rank?
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims Australia is ranked 21st in global competitiveness, 128th when it comes to burden of government regulation and second last in productivity growth.
column17: The claims: Tony Abbott says Australia is ranked 21st in global competitiveness, 128th when it comes to burden of government regulation and second last in productivity growth.
column18: The verdict: Mr Abbott quoted his sources accurately. The information they provide, however, is of questionable value.

column3: Fact check: how does Japan compare with other whaling nations?
column4: Japan claims almost 10 countries, including the US, Canada, Norway, Iceland, Denmark and Russia engage in whaling.
column17: Nori Shikata says almost 10 countries, including the US, Canada, Norway, Iceland, Denmark and Russia engage in whaling.
column18: There are at least 10 countries that undertake some kind of whaling activity. But Japan is the only one with a program that goes beyond its own territorial and economic boundaries. Japan's program is also the largest and covers more ocean than any other program.

column3: Single-decker v double-decker trains: Barry O'Farrell's claim doubtful
column4: NSW Premier Barry O'Farrell claims single-decker trains can carry more passengers per hour overall than double-decker trains because people can move on and off more quickly.
column17: Barry O'Farrell says single-decker trains can carry more people than double-decker ones because people can move on and off more quickly.
column18: Passengers can move on and off single-decker trains more quickly than double-decker ones, but experts say double-deckers carry so many more passengers that, per hour, they outdo single-deckers.

column3: Attorney-General George Brandis ill-informed on people's 'right to be bigots'
column4: Attorney-General George Brandis claims people have a right to be bigots and to say things that other people find offensive.
column17: Attorney-General George Brandis says people have a right to be bigots and to say things that other people find offensive.
column18: Senator Brandis's view is ill-informed. There are many laws in Australia which stop people saying things that other people find offensive, insulting or bigoted.

column3: Is it a crime to offend someone under the Racial Discrimination Act?
column4: Alan Tudge, Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, claims that under the Racial Discrimination Act, offensive language can be considered a crime.
column17: Alan Tudge says under the Racial Discrimination Act it can be considered a crime to offend someone.
column18: Mr Tudge is incorrect. The conduct described in section 18C of the Act is not criminal.

column3: Does Australia make it hard for Chinese tourists to apply for a visa?
column4: James Packer claims Australia does not accept online visa applications from China, and that Chinese people have to apply in English.
column17: James Packer says Australia does not accept online visa applications from China, and that Chinese people have to apply in English.
column18: Mr Packer is correct. Australia does require Chinese people to complete visa applications in English and on paper.

column3: Does Australia have a revenue problem, as ACOSS chief executive Cassandra Goldie claims?
column4: ACOSS chief executive Cassandra Goldie claims Australia is one of the lowest taxing countries in the OECD.
column17: Cassandra Goldie says Australia is one of the lowest taxing countries in the OECD and revenue is a problem.
column18: Australia pays lower levels of tax than most other OECD nations. However government spending has been increasing, and balancing the budget could be achieved by targeting either revenue or spending or both. Whether Australia has a revenue problem is arguable.

column3: Will one in three Australian babies live to 100 as Treasurer Joe Hockey says?
column4: Treasurer Joe Hockey is arguing for an increase in Australia's pension age to 70, saying one in three babies born today is likely to live to 100.
column17: Joe Hockey says one in every three Australian children born today will probably live to 100.
column18: UK research predicts one in three babies will live to 100 but Australian projections range from one in four to one in 37. Mr Hockey is making an informed guess.

column3: Is the evidence on GP co-payments as bad as Labor says?
column4: Acording to opposition health spokeswomen Catherine King the introduction of co-payments results in people avoiding seeing a doctor when they are sick and then ending up in emergency departments.
column17: Catherine King says evidence shows that GP co-payments mean people avoid doctor visits, end up sicker and end up in emergency departments.
column18: While Ms King is correct that the average person will visit the GP fewer times, there is only evidence to suggest the low income and chronically ill will get sicker. No studies could be found about the direct impact of GP co-payments on emergency departments.

column3: Has the Government doubled the budget deficit?
column4: Treasurer Joe Hockey is the "Masterchef of cooking the books" according to his Opposition counterpart Chris Bowen, who has repeatedly accused the Coalition of using "voodoo economics" to create a sense of crisis to justify dramatic spending cuts in the budget.
column17: Chris Bowen says Joe Hockey has doubled the deficit by changes to Government spending and changes to Government assumptions.
column18: Since the election, the official forecast deficit has doubled. The economic assumptions are different from those used before the election, and spending decisions have been made that were not in the previous forecasts. Mr Bowen's claim checks out.

column3: Are only 2pc of incomes over $100,000 earned by women under 50?
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims only 2 per cent of incomes over $100,000 are earned by women under 50. The actual figure is considerably higher.
column17: Tony Abbott says only 2 per cent of incomes over $100,000 are earned by women under 50.
column18: 15 per cent of incomes over $100,000 are earned by women under 50. If Mr Abbott had said that women of child-bearing age who earn over $100,000 are almost 2 per cent of all taxpayers, then he would have been correct.

column3: Fact check: Chris Bowen scaremongering on return of old-style commissions for financial advisers
column4: Commentary around the Federal Government's proposed changes to financial advice laws suggests the financial planning and advice industry is about to return to the bad old days when retirees lost their life savings in dodgy investments that paid big commissions to their advisers.
column17: Chris Bowen says the Government's changes to financial advice laws will bring back the type of commissions that encouraged financial advisers to recommend risky investments.
column18: The proposed changes will only apply to some forms of general advice. They do not bring back old-style commissions.

column3: Jenny Macklin's attack on Abbott's age pension, parental leave plans unfounded
column4: Opposition spokeswoman for families and payments Jenny Macklin https://www.abc.net.au/news/5421798 the Government wants to cut the conditions for age pensioners while paying wealthy women $50,000 to have a baby.
column17: Jenny Macklin says the Government has twisted priorities because it wants to cut the conditions for age pensioners while paying wealthy women $50,000 to have a baby.
column18: The Government is not cutting conditions for current age pensioners now or in the future, and while women on any income over $100,000 would be able to receive a payment of $50,000 under the Coalition's paid parental leave scheme, the scheme would deliver higher benefits to women on all incomes than they currently receive. Ms Macklin's claim is unfounded.

column3: Commission of Audit chairman Tony Shepherd incorrect on doctor visits
column4: The National Commission of Audit chairman Tony Shepherd claims that on average, Australians visit a doctor more than 11 times a year when they don't need to, and that a $15 co-payment for each visit would give them "cause for thought."
column17: Tony Shepherd says on average Australians go to the doctor 11 times a year.
column18: Australians visit the GP around five times a year, and visit the doctor, which has a broader definition, between six and seven times a year. Mr Shepherd is incorrect.

column3: Is Cambodia engulfed in a human rights crisis?
column4: Immigration Minister Scott Morrison wants refugees on Nauru sent to Cambodia, but Human rights lawyer David Manne claims independent evidence shows Cambodia is in no position to resettle refugees.
column17: David Manne says independent evidence clearly shows that Cambodia is engulfed in a human rights crisis.
column18: Evidence shows Cambodia is suffering from the fallout of a flawed election and violent protests that followed. Opposition MPs are refusing to accept the result of the election and there are real concerns about violence perpetrated by armed forces largely controlled by the ruling political party.

column3: Christopher Pyne's claim that graduates earn more is overblown
column4: Education Minister Christopher Pyne claims university students have a less than 1 per cent unemployment rate and, over a lifetime, earn 75 per cent more than those who don't go to university.
column17: Christopher Pyne says university students have a less than 1 per cent unemployment rate and over a lifetime earn 75 per cent more than someone who doesn't go to university.
column18: Of all university graduates, 3.3 per cent are unemployed. Some reports say university graduates earn about 75 per cent more than year 12 finishers, but others put the figure as low as 30 per cent. Mr Pyne's claim is overblown.

column3: Foreign aid cuts make up one fifth of budget savings
column4: World Vision Australia chief executive Tim Costello claims foreign aid cuts make up 20 per cent of the budget savings, while aid expenditure is only 1.3 per cent of the total budget.
column17: Tim Costello says foreign aid cuts make up 20 per cent of the budget savings, while aid expenditure is only 1.3 per cent of the total budget.
column18: Cuts to foreign aid account for 21 per cent of the total budget savings, and aid is 1.22 per cent of budget spending and forecast to fall.

column3: Will Australia's new medical research fund be the biggest in the world?
column4: Treasurer Joe Hockey claims within six years Australia will have "the biggest medical research endowment fund in the world".
column17: Joe Hockey says within six years Australia will have "the biggest medical research endowment fund in the world".
column18: There is at least one bigger medical research fund in the world, and some governments spend more money each year on medical research than the new Australian fund will distribute.

column3: Fact check: Will Abbott's fuel excise hike cost families 40c a week?
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims the reintroduction of fuel excise indexation will cost the average family 40 cents a week in the first year.
column17: Tony Abbott says the reintroduction of fuel excise indexation will cost the average family 40 cents a week in the first year.
column18: Mr Abbott's 40-cent claim applies to "the average household" rather than "the average family". For some families, such as a couple with dependent children, that figure can be 55 cents extra per week. Mr Abbott is close to the mark.

column3: Is the Government's plan to charge interest on existing student loans a broken contract?
column4: Greens Higher Education spokeswoman Lee Rhiannon claims the Government's plan to charge interest of up to 6 per cent on student debts amounts to a broken contract.
column17: Greens Higher Education spokeswoman Lee Rhiannon says the Government's plan to charge interest of up to 6 per cent on student debts constitutes a broken contract.
column18: There appears to be no legal contract between students and the Government over HELP debts. If Senator Rhiannon was referring to a broader "breach of faith", it is worth noting that charging interest on existing HELP-style loans would be unlikely to fly in the private sector. Senator Rhiannon's claim is debatable.

column3: Fact check: Is the Government paying $1 billion a month in interest on its debt?
column4: Treasurer Joe Hockey claims the Government is paying one billion dollars every month in interest on the debt that Labor left.
column17: Treasurer Joe Hockey says the Government is paying one billion dollars every month in interest on the debt that Labor left.
column18: Using either gross debt or net debt as a measure, Mr Hockey's claim is exaggerated.

column3: Fact check: Has public hospital funding been cut by $50 billion?
column4: Opposition spokeswoman for health Catherine King claims the budget cuts a "whopping" $50 billion from Australia's public hospitals.
column17: Catherine King says this budget cuts a "whopping" $50 billion from Australia's public hospitals.
column18: Ms King doesn't make it clear that the forecast changes to hospital funding are over 10 years. In fact, the Government is claiming savings of only $2 billion from hospitals over four years. Whether there will be a $50 billion difference to hospital funding over the next decade is impossible to verify.

column3: Fact check: Is the Abbott Government cutting $30 billion from school funding?
column4: Opposition education spokeswoman Kate Ellis claims Tony Abbott and Christopher Pyne have announced $30 billion in cuts to Australian schools.
column17: Kate Ellis says Tony Abbott and Christopher Pyne have announced $30 billion in cuts to Australian schools.
column18: The Government did not cut $30 billion from schools in the May budget. The $30 billion figure is calculated over a 10 year period starting in 2017. It adds up the difference between the increase in funding that Labor says it would have delivered and the increase the Government may deliver. There is too much uncertainty for such a long-term estimate to be reliable measure of either cuts or savings.

column3: Fact check: Tony Abbott overstating household savings from axing the carbon tax
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims every Australian household will benefit by $550 a year if the carbon tax is axed.
column17: Tony Abbott says Australian households will benefit to the tune of $550 a year if the carbon tax is axed.
column18: Based on Treasury modelling, households will be better off by around $550 in 2014-15 if the current legislation is scrapped. However the following year the estimated impact on households drops to $280.

column3: Fact check: Does ANZUS commit the US to come to Australia's aid, as Foreign Minister Julie Bishop claims?
column4: Foreign Minister Julie Bishop claims at the heart of the ANZUS treaty is a commitment for signatories to come to one another's aid in the worst of times.
column17: Julie Bishop says at the heart of the ANZUS treaty is a commitment for signatories to come to one another's aid in the worst of times.
column18: The treaty calls on signatories to "consult" and "act" if another party is attacked, but does not specify what that action should be. Without saying what she means by "come to one another's aid", Ms Bishop's claim, like the ANZUS treaty itself, is ambiguous.

column3: Fact check: Tony Abbott's claim carbon schemes being discarded doesn't check out
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims emissions trading schemes are being discarded around the world, not adopted.
column17: Tony Abbott says emissions trading schemes are being discarded around the world, not adopted
column18: While there is uncertainty in the international carbon pricing market and global agreements are weak and non-binding, individual nations and sub-national regions are increasingly creating carbon trading schemes of their own.

column3: Fact check: Does the federal budget cut $80 billion from hospitals and schools?
column4: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims the budget conceals an $80 billion cut to hospitals and schools. Prime Minister Tony Abbott disagrees.
column17: The budget papers say the Government will achieve $80 billion in savings from hospitals and schools. Bill Shorten says this is a cut. Tony Abbott says it isn't.
column18: The debate over the $80 billion - claimed by the Government as savings and by the Opposition as cuts - is hot air.

column3: Fact check: Is the disability support pension a 'set and forget' payment?
column4: Social Services Minister Kevin Andrews claims the disability support pension is a 'set and forget' payment irrespective of their long-term ability to work.
column17: Kevin Andrews says the disability support pension is a 'set and forget' payment.
column18: For some recipients, the disability pension could be a 'set and forget' payment, but there is also evidence to suggest some people are not reviewed because they have a long-term disability and cannot work. There's more to the story.

column3: Fact check: Can clean coal technology halve emissions within 5 years?
column4: Environment Minister Greg Hunt claims technology which will be available over the next three to five years will reduce emissions from coal-fired power stations by up to 30 to 50 per cent.
