column17: Greg Hunt says technology which will be available over the next three to five years will reduce emissions from coal-fired power stations by up to 30 to 50 per cent.
column18: The technology remains in a development phase and is not realistically expected to be commercially operative and rolled out within three to five years. No other clean coal technology sufficient to cut emissions from current generators by up to 50 per cent is economically viable at industrial scale in Australia, or expected to become viable within the next five years.

column3: Fact check: Rupert Murdoch misleading on North and South Poles
column4: Media magnate Rupert Murdoch claims the North Pole is melting "a bit, but the South Pole is getting bigger".
column17: Rupert Murdoch says the North Pole is melting "a bit" but the South Pole is getting bigger.
column18: Antarctic sea ice is increasing, but the Antarctic ice sheet is decreasing. In the Arctic, both sea ice and the Greenland ice sheet are decreasing significantly.

column3: Fact check: Too soon to know if e-cigarettes help people quit smoking
column4: The evidence does not support the idea that e-cigarettes help people stop smoking.
column17: The executive director of public health at the WA Department of Health, Dr Tarun Weeramanthri, says "some people will say [e-cigarettes] helped me quit, but when we look at the evidence, many more people just keep smoking both normal cigarettes and e-cigarettes".
column18: It's too soon to know.

column3: Fact check: Are 75pc of Australia's living species largely unknown?
column4: An estimated 75 per cent of Australia's biodiversity is largely unknown.
column17: Jo Harding, the manager of Bush Blitz, says there's estimated to be about 75 per cent of Australia's biodiversity that's largely unknown
column18: Ms Harding's claim checks out.

column3: Fact check: Joe Hockey's 'poor people' don't have cars, don't drive far claim, misleading
column4: Treasurer Joe Hockey claims higher income people pay the most fuel tax because poor people don't own cars or don't drive very far.
column17: Joe Hockey says higher income people pay the most fuel tax, because poor people don't own cars or don't drive very far.
column18: While high income Australians spend more in dollar terms on fuel, the impact on their budget is less. Mr Hockey's claim that raising fuel tax will affect high income earners more is misleading.

column3: Fact check: Will Australia ever be the 'food bowl of Asia'?
column4: Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce tempers expectations that Australia can become the 'food bowl of Asia'.
column17: Coalition policy documents say Australia could become the 'food bowl of Asia', but Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce says the notion is ridiculous.

column3: Fact check: Palmer United Party Senator Jacqui Lambie incorrect on defence spending
column4: Is Australia's defence spending as a ratio of GDP the lowest it has been since pre-World War II?
column17: Jacqui Lambie says Australia's defence spending as a ratio of GDP is the lowest it's been since pre-World War II.
column18: In 1938-39 defence spending as a percentage of GDP was 1.5 per cent. The lowest it has been since then is 1.62 per cent in 2002-03 and again in 2012-13. It was 1.71 per cent in 2013-14, and is projected to be higher in 2014-15.

column3: Fact check: Labor blocking $5 billion of its own savings measures
column4: Finance Minister Mathias Cormann claims Labor is opposing $5 billion in savings that it initiated when it was in government.
column17: Mathias Cormann says Labor is opposing $5 billion in savings that it initiated when it was in government.
column18: Labor is blocking three measures which would save the budget more than $5 billion and which it initiated when in government.

column3: Fact check: Will Australian universities 'slide into mediocrity' without reform?
column4: Education Minister Christopher Pyne claims that without deregulation Australia's universities will slide into mediocrity and be overtaken by Asian competitors.
column17: Christopher Pyne says Australia cannot have no reform to its universities or they will slide into mediocrity and be overtaken by Asian competitors.
column18: On the available evidence, without Mr Pyne's reforms, it seems unlikely Australian universities will slide into mediocrity.

column3: Fact check: Who has a say in sending Australian troops to war?
column4: Foreign Minister Julie Bishop claims the government of the day has the ultimate responsibility for making decisions involving Australia's military.
column17: Julie Bishop says the government of the day has the ultimate responsibility for making decisions involving Australia's military.
column18: Since federation in 1901, and for all conflicts since World War I, the Prime Minister and Cabinet have made all decisions about deploying troops.

column3: Fact check: Do young, childless women earn more than men?
column4: American academic and commentator Kay Hymowitz claims childless women in their twenties in the US earn more than men.
column17: American academic and commentator Kay Hymowitz says childless women in their twenties in the US are earning more than men.
column18: Research shows that for young women, both in the United States and Australia, the gender wage gap still exists. Ms Hymowitz's claim is based on data collected six years ago, which did not take into account women's earnings outside big metropolitan centres or in part-time work.

column3: Fact check: Tony Abbott incorrect on impact of superannuation changes on workers
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims delaying a mandated increase to compulsory superannuation contributions will not leave employees worse off.
column17: Tony Abbott says delaying an increase to compulsory superannuation contributions is "not an adverse change" and that "no-one is going backwards".
column18: Workers are unlikely to receive in wages what they will lose in superannuation. Even if workers did receive higher wages, many would pay tax at a higher rate.

column3: Fact check: Will 50pc of Australians die before they can access their superannuation?
column4: Palmer United Party leader Clive Palmer claims it is a "statistical fact" that more than 50 per cent of Australians will be dead by the time they get access to their super.
column17: Clive Palmer says it is a "statistical fact" that over 50 per cent of Australians will be dead by the time they get access to their super.
column18: More than 89 per cent of people are expected live beyond the age of 65 years, when everyone can access their super. Mr Palmer is wrong.

column3: Fact check: Have 100,000 new jobs been created this year?
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims more than 100,000 new jobs were created in his first year in office.
column17: Tony Abbott says over 100,000 new jobs have been created since the end of last year.
column18: According to the July ABS Labour Force survey, the number of people employed full-time and part-time between December 2013 and July 2014 rose by 109,300.

column3: Fact check: Health Minister Peter Dutton's dementia facts flawed
column4: Health Minister Peter Dutton claims the number of people diagnosed with dementia will soar to 7,500 a week "in a number of years" from 170 per week today.
column17: Peter Dutton says it's a fact that 170 people per week today are being diagnosed with dementia, but in a number of years it'll be 7,500 a week.
column18: Mr Dutton predicts a fortyfold increase in the number of dementia cases being diagnosed each week. This is not supported by the evidence, which predicts cases will triple over the next four decades.

column3: Fact check: Tony Abbott exaggerating India's 'absolutely impeccable record' on nuclear non-proliferation
column4: As the government formalises an agreement to sell uranium to India, over-turning a decades-old ban, Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims the Asian nation has an "absolutely impeccable record" on nuclear non-proliferation.
column17: Tony Abbott says India has an "absolutely impeccable record" when it comes to nuclear non-proliferation.
column18: India has an absolutely impeccable record when it comes to preventing the horizontal spread of nuclear weapons to other states. However, it has increased its nuclear weapons stockpile, conducted nuclear testing and refused to sign the NPT. There are also question marks over its safety procedures.

column3: It's war, not 'a mission': Abbott incorrect on Iraq action
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims Australian use of air strikes and Australian special forces to fight Islamic state militants in Iraq amounts to "a mission" rather than "a war".
column17: Tony Abbott says Australia's commitment in Iraq is "best described as a mission rather than as a war".
column18: Experts say war is determined by the intensity of hostilities and whether the opposition is an organised armed group. Mr Abbott is incorrect.

column3: Fact check: Journalists face 10 years' jail for exposing security agency bungles
column4: Labor frontbencher Anthony Albanese claims the Government's new terror laws mean members of the media face potential penalties of five to 10 years' jail for exposing what might be an error made by security agencies.
column17: Anthony Albanese says the Government's new terror laws mean members of the media face potential penalties of five to 10 years' jail for exposing what might be an error made by security agencies.
column18: New provisions do impose potential penalties of up to five or 10 years' jail for exposing errors made by security agencies. Mr Albanese's claim checks out.

column3: Fact check: Science, research and innovation spending cut to 'historic low'
column4: Greens deputy leader Adam Bandt claims the Federal Government has cut spending on science, research and innovation to a "historic low".
column17: Adam Bandt says the Federal Government has cut spending on science, research and innovation to an "historic low".
column18: The Parliamentary Library estimates that research and development spending will be 0.56 per cent of GDP in 2014-15. This is the equal lowest since records began in 1978-79.

column3: Fact check: Does a farmer die by suicide every four days in Australia as Bob Katter says?
column4: Federal MPmBob Katter claims a farmer commits suicide every four days in Australia.
column17: Bob Katter says a farmer dies by suicide every four days in Australia.
column18: Mr Katter is basing his claim on data from the 1980s and 1990s. More recent data shows that farmers' suicide rates are elevated when compared to the general public, however the rates differ dramatically across regions.

column3: Fact check: Was Hong Kong ever promised democracy?
column4: Martin Lee, a lawyer who helped draft Hong Kong's constitution, claims the people of Hong Kong were promised democracy.
column17: Martin Lee, a lawyer who helped draft Hong Kong's constitution, says the people of Hong Kong were promised democracy.
column18: Any claim that Hong Kong has been promised democracy should be tempered by evidence that China did not explicitly included a timetable for steps to universal suffrage, did not define democratic principles, and did not allow international standards for free and fair elections to apply in Hong Kong.

column3: Fact check: Health Minister Peter Dutton misleading on Red Cross Ebola funding
column4: Health Minister Peter Dutton claims the Federal Government provided $18 million to non-government organisations such as the Red Cross to fight Ebola in Africa.
column17: Peter Dutton says the Federal Government has provided $18 million to services like the Red Cross to fight Ebola in Africa.
column18: The Red Cross has not received specific funding from the Federal Government to support its Ebola program in West Africa. The Federal Government has provided $2.5 million to four Australian NGOs: Caritas, Plan International, Save the Children and World Vision.

column3: Fact check: Is workplace discrimination against older people costing $10 billion a year?
column4: Age Discrimination Commissioner Susan Ryan claims Australia is losing about $10 billion a year by failing to employ more people over the age of 55.
column17: Susan Ryan says Australia is losing about $10 billion a year by not employing more people over 55.
column18: Experts say the calculation is problematic because it uses GDP per capita instead of the wages older workers would actually earn, doesn't take account of the number of older Australians who want to work part-time and assumes the productivity of all older Australians not working is the same as the rest of the workforce.

column3: Fact check: Are de facto relationships more unstable than marriages?
column4: Social Services Minister Kevin Andrews claims data shows that de facto relationships have a higher incidence of break-up than marriages.
column17: Kevin Andrews says the data shows de facto relationships are more likely to break up than marriages.
column18: For the majority of couples, a de facto relationship is the pathway to marriage. Still, for those who never marry, the chance of separating is more than six times higher. Mr Andrews's claim checks out.

column3: Fact File: Backing the Melbourne Cup favourite: Are the odds in your favour?
column4: How often does the favourite actually win? And would you be ahead or behind if you bet on the favourite every year?

column3: Fact check: How much will the fuel tax hike leave you out of pocket?
column4: The Abbott government claims an increase in the fuel excise will cost households an extra 40 cents a week. But the Australian Automobile Association says the Government is being disengenuous because the average motorist will actually pay about $140 extra a year.
column17: Andrew McKellar says the average motorist will pay somewhere in the region of $140 extra a year with an increase in the fuel tax excise from November 10.
column18: Mr McKellar is assuming a higher level of fuel consumption than is supported by official data. His calculation is also based on costs that won't apply for three years. His claim is exaggerated.

column3: Fact check: Are feral cats killing over 20 billion native animals a year?
column4: Environment Minister Greg Hunt claims up to 20 million feral cats are each killing four native Australian animals a night, destroying over 20 billion animals a year.
column17: Greg Hunt says up to 20 million feral cats are each killing four native Australian animals a night, destroying over 20 billion animals a year.
column18: The number of feral cats in Australia is impossible to calculate because of density variation, and the way the population fluctuates with prey availability and climate. The number of native Australian animals killed by feral cats each night is also difficult to calculate, due to differences in the size of prey. Mr Hunt's claim is unverifiable.

column3: Fact check: Are Victorians waiting longer than ever for ambulances to arrive?
column4: Victorian Opposition Leader Daniel Andrews claims ambulance service has never been worse, with response times longer than ever before.
column17: Daniel Andrews says ambulances are taking longer to arrive than ever before.
column18: None of the data Fact Check looked at showed a worse percentage of code one response times than the two most recent years, during the Napthine Government. But there is no data for the early years, and since the 1980s, response times have been measured in different ways, making a direct comparison impossible.

column3: Fact check: Did Joh Bjelke-Petersen instigate the Fitzgerald inquiry?
column4: Barnaby Joyce claims Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen brought about the Fitzgerald inquiry.
column17: Barnaby Joyce says Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen brought about the Fitzgerald inquiry.
column18: It was deputy premier and police minister Bill Gunn who announced that the Queensland government would hold an inquiry into police corruption. The formal statement of Tony Fitzgerald's appointment and the terms of reference was made by Mr Gunn as acting premier and the attorney-general Paul Clauson. The evidence on the public record points to Mr Gunn being the instigator of the inquiry.

column3: Fact check: Hockey overstates the power of congress to block Obama's emissions pledge
column4: Treasurer Joe Hockey claims it will be difficult for US president Barack Obama to deliver on climate change pledges because he must first get past a hostile US congress.
column17: Joe Hockey says Barack Obama has to get any initiative on climate change through a hostile US congress.
column18: The executive powers of the US president to impose stricter emissions standards are well established. Mr Obama's recent agreement with China does not have to be ratified by congress. However, Republicans in congress could try to limit funding to the Environmental Protection Agency, which implements any new standards. Mr Hockey's claim is overstated.

column3: Fact check: Do Australia, US 'compare favourably' on emissions targets?
column4: Environment Minister Greg Hunt claims Australia's emissions reduction efforts can be compared favourably to the United States.
column17: Environment Minister Greg Hunt says Australia's emissions reduction efforts can be compared favourably to the United States.
column18: Mr Hunt's figures are supported by research, but do not represent all factors or methods that experts say are needed to measure and compare nations' emissions targets.

column3: Fact check: Does the gap between rich and poor affect a country's growth?
column4: Opposition foreign affairs spokeswoman Tanya Plibersek claims OECD data shows that the larger the difference between rich and poor countries, the less likely a nation's growth will be strong.
column17: Tanya Plibersek says terrific OECD data shows that the larger the difference between the richest and the poorest, the less likely it is that a country's growth will be strong.
column18: Ms Plibersek's definitive claim that the "OECD has terrific data"  is overreach.

column3: Fact check: Has train punctuality improved under the Napthine Government?
column4: Victorian Premier Denis Napthine claims his Government has "improved train punctuality".
column17: Denis Napthine says his Government has "improved train punctuality".
column18: With punctuality running at over 92 per cent across the Metro network, trains are more often on time now than under the previous Labor government.

column3: Fact check: Has the Abbott Government 'dropped the ball' on unemployment?
column4: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims unemployment stood at 5.7 per cent when the Abbott government came to office in September 2013, but it rose to 6.2 per cent by December 2014.
column17: Bill Shorten says Tony Abbott has "dropped the ball" on the challenges of unemployment.
column18: The unemployment rate has risen under the Coalition, but it was also rising under Labor. The same can be said for the youth unemployment rate. Experts say the labour market has been deteriorating since 2011.

column3: Fact check: Campbell Newman exaggerating crime statistics ahead of Qld poll
column4: Queensland Premier Campbell Newman claims Queensland crime rates have "gone down very very significantly" because of Liberal policy.
column17: Campbell Newman says Queensland crime rates have "gone down very very significantly" because of LNP policy.
column18: Qld crime rates have been dropping steadily for over 10 years, and the most recent data does not show a significant change in that trend. It is too soon to determine the impact of LNP policies on the trend, and individual statistics cited by the premier don't tell the full story. The claim is exaggerated.

column3: Fact check: Labor claims unemployment in Qld highest in 11 years
column4: Queensland Opposition Leader Annastacia Palaszczuk claims there are almost 31,000 more Queenslanders without a job since March 2012 and blames the Liberal government for the rise.
column17: Queensland Opposition Leader Annastacia Palaszczuk says the "jobless rate is the highest for 11 years... There are almost 31,000 more Queenslanders without a job since March 2012". She blames the LNP government.
column18: Ms Palaszczuk's claim is backed up by the ABS's official data. But the national data shows Queensland is not the only state with rising unemployment, and experts told Fact Check that state governments have little control over employment. Ms Palaszczuk is correct, but there's more to it.

column3: Fact check: Did jobs growth triple in 2014, as Tony Abbott says?
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims Australia's "jobs growth in 2014 was triple the rate in 2013 – with 4,000 new jobs a week."
column17: Prime Minister Tony Abbott says Australia's jobs rate is on the up. "Jobs growth in 2014 was triple the rate in 2013 – with 4,000 new jobs a week."
column18: The latest ABS seasonally adjusted estimates show that employment was rising in 2014 at triple the rate of 2013. But the ABS recommends using trend data to measure employment. The trend estimates show the rate of growth in 2014 was double that of 2013. Experts have mixed views on which estimates should be used. They say an assessment of the strength of the jobs market should take into account that unemployment rose in 2014. There is more to the story.

column3: Fact check: Joe Hockey's claim that people work half the year to pay income tax incorrect
column4: Treasurer Joe Hockey claims Australian income tax rates are a disincentive to earn. But how much income tax do Australians pay?

column3: Fact check: Triggs correct on the length of time children spent in detention
column4: Australian Human Rights Commission president Gillian Triggs claims that in the first months of the Coalition Government, the time children spent in immigration detention "was reaching quite exceptional levels"
column17: Australian Human Rights Commission president Gillian Triggs says in the first months of the Coalition Government the time children spent in immigration detention "was reaching quite exceptional levels".
column18: Data provided to the commission by the immigration department shows the number of children in detention for over three months more than doubled in the first months after the Coalition took office. In January 2014 it was the highest it had been in five years. Immigration department data shows that the overall number of people in long-term detention, which can be extrapolated to children, continued to increase during 2014, and only declined in late 2014. Professor Triggs is correct.

column3: Fact check: Hockey over-eggs 'borrowing $100 million a day' claim
column4: Treasurer Joe Hockey has warned that Australia is at a tipping point and living beyond its means.
column17: Joe Hockey has warned that Australia is at a "tipping point" and living beyond its means. "We cannot continue to go on borrowing $100 million a day as a government just to pay our daily bills," he said.
column18: Mr Hockey is using a conservative figure to estimate the daily cost of borrowing, but economists said his statement that we are at a "tipping point" is open to debate. Australia's debt and deficit are not at particularly high levels historically, or internationally, and investors are prepared to lend more to the federal government. Mr Hockey's claim is over-egged.

column3: Fact check: No proof the death penalty prevents crime
column4: Victorian Supreme Court judge Lex Lasry claims the death penalty does not deter crime, "it's just a terrible thing to do".
column17: Victorian Supreme Court judge Lex Lasry says the death penalty does not deter crime, "it's just a terrible thing to do".
column18: There is scant research on whether the death penalty deters drug trafficking. Experts who have considered the issue of the death penalty as a punishment for murder, and in some cases drug offences, around the world, say there is not enough evidence to conclude that the death penalty deters.

column3: Fact check: Did the Government inherit the 'worst set of accounts' in history?
column4: Deputy Liberal Leader Julie Bishop claims the Abbott Government inherited the worst set of financial accounts in Australia's history.
column17: Deputy Liberal Leader Julie Bishop says the Abbott Government inherited the worst set of financial accounts in Australia's history.
column18: Large borrowings to finance Australia's participation in World War I and World War II and the impact of the Great Depression led to much higher deficits and levels of debt than any government has experienced since. The Howard Government also inherited more gross and net debt and a higher budget deficit relative to GDP than the Abbott Government. Ms Bishop is wrong.

column3: Fact check: Did the Abbott Government cut $1 billion from child care?
column4: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims the Federal Government has cut $1 billion from childcare.
column17: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims the Federal Government has cut $1 billion from childcare.
column18: Labor has detailed over $1 billion in cuts to childcare programs, but the list includes $336 million in programs where overall spending is increasing and $95 million in programs that were due to expire. What's more, some of the money Labor claims has been cut was redirected to other child care programs. Mr Shorten's claim is overreach.

column3: Fact check: Did NSW Labor fail to deliver 'a single railway line'?
column4: NSW Premier Mike Baird claims Labor did not deliver a single railway line when in government.
column17: NSW Premier Mike Baird says Labor did not deliver a single railway line when in government.
column18: Mr Baird's claim ignores projects that were started and finished under the previous government like the Epping to Chatswood line and the Sydney airport line. While Labor promised a lot of railways that were never built, Mr Baird's claim that Labor "did not deliver a single railway line" is overstated.

column3: Fact check: Is crime in NSW the lowest it's been in 25 years?
column4: Putting law and order policy at the forefront of his re-election campaign, NSW Premier Mike Baird claims crime in the state is at its lowest level in decades.
column17: NSW Premier Mike Baird claims that crime in the state is at its lowest level in decades. "In the most recent statistics, crime is at its lowest level in 25 years," Mr Baird said.
column18: The rates of most crimes have been dropping since 2001 and are at lower levels than they were 25 years ago. But domestic violence and sexual assault rates have risen since the early 1990s. Experts say the overall "level" of crime ignores trends in serious crimes that are less common or might not be as widely reported. Mr Baird's claim is selective.

column3: Fact check: Does the minimum wage increase unemployment?
column4: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims the evidence from Europe shows the minimum wage doesn't contribute to unemployment levels.
column17: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten says the evidence from Europe shows the minimum wage doesn't contribute to unemployment levels.
column18: Mr Shorten's claim is backed up by the research on overall employment levels, but when looking at young people or the level of the minimum wage it's not so straightforward. There's more to the story.

column3: Fact check: Did the Coalition Government cut $3b from the NSW health budget?
column4: NSW Opposition Leader Luke Foley claims the Coalition Government has cut $3 billion from health.
column17: NSW Opposition Leader Luke Foley says the Coalition Government has cut $3 billion from health.
column18: Experts told Fact Check that efficiency savings that are reinvested in health cannot be regarded as a cut. The budget papers show that spending on health has increased by $3.2 billion since Labor's last budget and by $2.3 billion in the three years since the measures were announced. Mr Foley is incorrect.

column3: Fact check: Does privatisation increase electricity bills?
column4: NSW Opposition Leader Luke Foley claims electricity privatisation pushes up power prices and households in privatised South Australia have the highest bills.
column17: NSW Opposition Leader Luke Foley says electricity privatisation pushes up power prices and households in privatised South Australia have the highest bills.
column18: While one report did find SA had the highest bills, others don't back that up. Whether comparing electricity bills, prices or the relative price index of electricity in each state, there is no consistent link between privatisation and what consumers pay for their electricity. Mr Foley's claim is spin.

column3: Fact check: Banning dumping of dredge spoil on the Great Barrier Reef
column4: A recent move by the Federal Government to ban the disposal of dredge spoil near the Great Barrier Reef has been met with scepticism by environmental campaigners concerned for the health of the reef.
column17: Queensland Greens Senator Larissa Waters says that 80 per cent of dredge spoil dumped in the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area is in the 1 per cent of the listed area that is outside the coverage of a new ban on dumping proposed by the Federal Government. She wants the Government to cover the entire area.
column18: The Federal Government's ban does exclude the area where 80 per cent of the dumping occurred in the last five years, but the Queensland Government has agreed to cover that area with a similar ban. Senator Waters's criticism is beside the point.

column3: Fact check: Are 80,000 Victorians using ice?
column4: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews claims about 80,000 Victorians used the drug ice in 2014.
column17: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews says about 80,000 Victorians used the drug ice in the previous year.
column18: The best data available says roughly 90,000 Victorians used methamphetamine in the last year. It appears unlikely that 8 out of 9 of these people used ice. The figure used by Mr Andrews is rubbery.

column3: NSW election: Get the facts behind the claims
column4: During the New South Wales election campaign both major parties have made claims in key policy battlegrounds. But how much of what the leaders claim checks out?

column3: Fact check: Do the states and territories need to agree to change the GST?
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims the Government cannot change the GST without the agreement of the states and territories, and consensus in the federal parliament.
column17: Prime Minister Tony Abbott says the Government cannot change the GST without the agreement of the states and territories, and consensus in the federal parliament.
column18: Legal experts say changing the GST simply requires amendments to the GST Act. The Government only needs a simple majority of both houses of parliament to do this. While it may be politically difficult, there is no legal barrier to the Commonwealth unilaterally changing the rate or base of the GST. Mr Abbott is being misleading.

column3: Fact check: Are superannuation tax breaks fair, or do they favour the rich?
column4: Shadow treasurer Chris Bowen claims the top 10 per cent of income earners get more than 30 per cent of tax concessions in superannuation.
column17: Shadow treasurer Chris Bowen says the top 10 per cent of income earners get more than 30 per cent of tax concessions in superannuation.
column18: Yes, Mr Bowen's claim that the top 10 per cent of income earners receive over 30 per cent of super tax concessions is correct, but when other government support is included, the imbalance is not so pronounced. There's more to it.

column3: Fact check: Does halal certification fund terrorism?
column4: One Nation founder Pauline Hanson claims that halal certification is a $3 trillion industry that funds Islamic organisations and terrorism.
column17: One Nation founder Pauline Hanson says that halal certification is a $3 trillion industry that funds Islamic organisations and terrorism.
column18: Ms Hanson's estimate of a $3 trillion industry conflates the value of the global food market with the value of the halal certification market. While the proceeds of halal certification do fund Islamic organisations, Fact Check could find no evidence money has ever flowed to terrorist groups. Ms Hanson's claim doesn't check out.

column3: Fact check: Did abolishing negative gearing push up rents?
column4: Treasurer Joe Hockey claims abolishing negative gearing could push up rents, because that's what happened in the 1980s.
column17: Treasurer Joe Hockey says abolishing negative gearing could push up rents, because that's what happened in the 1980s.
column18: During the period negative gearing was abolished rents notably increased only in Sydney and Perth. Other factors, including high interest rates and the share market boom, were also contributors to rent increases at the time. Mr Hockey's claim doesn't stack up.

column3: Fact check: How much is subsidising cheap paracetamol costing the government?
column4: Health Minister Sussan Ley claims subsidising paracetamol that can be bought cheaply without a prescription is costing the government $73 million a year.
column17: Health Minister Sussan Ley says subsidising paracetamol that can be bought without a prescription at "the supermarket and corner stores for around $2" is costing the government $73 million a year.
column18: Paracetamol prescriptions cost the government around $73 million a year on the PBS, but 85 per cent of that cost comes from prescriptions for people in chronic pain from osteoarthritis. The high dose, slow release paracetamol formulation they are prescribed can't be bought from a supermarket for $2. Ms Ley is incorrect.

column3: Promise tracker: Where does the Government stand ahead of the 2015 budget?
column4: ABC Fact Check is tracking the Coalition's pre-election commitments. See which promises the Government has kept which ones it has broken.

column3: Fact check: The Coalition's stance on paid parental leave 'double dipping'
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims the Coalition announced plans to stop new mothers "double dipping" on paid parental leave before the 2013 election.
column17: Prime Minister Tony Abbott says the Coalition announced plans to stop new mothers "double dipping" on paid parental leave before the 2013 election.
column18: The policy the Coalition took to the election didn't include ending double dipping and ensured most working women would have a far better deal with their paid parental leave. A pre-election costings document did flag scrapping double dipping for public servants, but it didn't say it would apply to women in the private sector. Mr Abbott's claim is misleading.

column3: Fact check: Andrew Forrest exaggerating big miner influence over iron ore
column4: Fortescue Metals Group chairman Andrew Forrest claims Australia is the world's biggest iron ore producer and has more control of iron ore than OPEC ever had of oil.
column17: Andrew Forrest says Australia is the world's biggest iron ore producer and has more control of iron ore than the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) ever had of oil.
column18: Australia is the biggest producer of iron ore in the world. It is also the largest exporter and has the largest iron ore reserves. But Australia's big producers, BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto do not "control more iron ore than OPEC ever did in oil". Mr Forrest's claim is exaggerated.

column3: Fact check: Where do Australians get illegal guns?
column4: Nationals Senator Bridget McKenzie claims most guns used in crime are illegally imported rather than coming from licensed owners.
column17: Nationals Senator Bridget McKenzie says most guns used in crime are illegally imported rather than coming from licensed owners.
column18: ABC Fact Check could find no study or evidence that proved the majority of guns used to commit crimes are illegally imported. Comprehensive data on the source of illegal guns in Australia is lacking. Senator McKenzie's claim is baseless.

column3: Fact check: Tony Abbott's claim Labor spent like 'drunken sailors' in office is spin
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims growth in spending is lower under the Coalition than it was under Labor.
column17: Prime Minister Tony Abbott says growth in spending is lower under the Coalition than it was under Labor.
column18: Experts say Labor's one-off stimulus spending to combat the GFC distorts Mr Abbott's comparison, and opposition in the Senate to proposed spending cuts could change the estimates for the Abbott Government. What's more, measured as a proportion of gross domestic product, spending under the Abbott Government has been higher than in all but one of Labor's years in government. Mr Abbott's claim is spin.

column3: Fact check: How does Australia's plan to strip foreign fighters of citizenship compare to other nations?
column4: Defending proposed changes to give him the power to strip Australian citizenship from dual nationals fighting with terrorist groups, Immigration Minister Peter Dutton claims Australia is not "ahead of the pack" as countries such as the UK, US, New Zealand and France  have similar laws.
column17: Immigration Minister Peter Dutton says Australia is not "ahead of the pack" by proposing to strip Australian citizenship from dual nationals who are fighting with terrorist groups. He says countries like the UK, US, New Zealand, France and Canada have similar laws.
column18: Each these nations have distinct laws around foreign fighters and revoking citizenship, so there is no real pack. The UK has gone further than Australia, while Canada sits just behind. France, the US and New Zealand have not gone as far as Australia proposes, and each has different laws. Mr Dutton's claim is overstated.

column3: Fact check: How can the GST on tampons be scrapped?
column4: Treasurer Joe Hockey and Prime Minister Tony Abbott claim they need the agreement of the states and territories to remove the GST from tampons and pads.
column17: Treasurer Joe Hockey and Prime Minister Tony Abbott say they need the agreement of the states and territories to remove the GST from tampons and pads.
column18: There's no legal barrier to the federal government changing the base or rate of the GST without state and territory permission. While it might be politically difficult, and not something any government would do lightly, claims that it's not possible to change the GST without state agreement are misleading.

column3: Fact Check: Amnesty International claim on 'shocking' Indigenous child incarceration rates checks out
column4: Amnesty International secretary general Salil Shetty claims the rate at which Western Australia jails Indigenous children is higher than the rate black children in the US are incarcerated.
column17: Amnesty International secretary general Salil Shetty claims that the rate that Western Australia jails Indigenous children is higher than the rate black children in the US are incarcerated.
column18: Indigenous children in Western Australia are incarcerated at a rate of 76 per 10,000, a higher rate than black children in the US are incarcerated, which is 52 per 10,000. Mr Shetty's claim checks out.

column3: Fact check: Do higher food star ratings always mean a healthier choice?
column4: The Federal Government health star rating system for food and drink products, "the more stars, the healthier", is not as straighforward as it sounds.
column17: The Federal Government says its health star rating system for food and drink products is simple and "the more stars, the healthier".
column18: Whilst experts agree that the system is valuable and useful when comparing foods within the same category, it produces anomalies when comparing products in different categories, such as comparing yoghurt and fruit juice. More stars does not always mean a healthier product.

column3: Fact check: Does a formal no case sink a constitutional referendum?
column4: Indigenous academic Marcia Langton claims constitutional recognition of Indigenous people will fail if conservatives lead a 'no case' against a proposed referendum.
column17: Marcia Langton says that all referendums with formal no cases have been voted down by a majority of Australians.
column18: While a formal no case supported by parliamentarians who vote against the referendum change is usually associated with referendum failure, three referendums have succeeded even with a no case. Professor Langton's claim is incorrect.

column3: Fact check: Does infrasound from wind farms make people sick?
column4: Liberal Democrats senator David Leyonhjelm claims the low frequency sound of wind farms "cause adverse health impacts".
column17: Liberal Democrats Senator David Leyonhjelm says that it is "well established that inappropriate levels of infrasound, regardless of the source, cause adverse health impacts".
column18: The assumption that infrasound causes illness does not have a strong basis in scientific evidence. Senator Leyonhjelm's claim is unproven.

column3: Fact check: Would paying people smugglers to turn back boats be illegal?
column4: Greens leader Richard Di Natale says if the Abbott Government paid people smugglers to turn boats back to Indonesia it would have been a breach of domestic and international law.
column17: Greens leader Richard Di Natale says if the Abbott Government paid people smugglers to turn boats back to Indonesia it would have been a breach of domestic and international law.
column18: Most legal experts told Fact Check that such payments would have likely breached both Australian and international law. Andreas Schloenhardt, from the University of Queensland, was not certain it was a breach, but did say such payments would "contravene the spirit" of international law. Senator Di Natale's claim checks out.

column3: Fact Check: Are millions of taxpayer dollars being wasted on poorly performing IVF clinics?
column4: A leading IVF expert claims secrecy around IVF clinic success rates is wasting millions of dollars worth of Medicare rebates, as poorly performing clinics take more cycles to have a baby.

column3: Fact check: Do nine in 10 Australians spend more than 90 minutes a day commuting?
column4: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims nine out of 10 Australians spend more than 90 minutes a day commuting to work.
column17: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten says nine out of 10 Australians spend more than 90 minutes a day commuting to work.
column18: While people living in the outer areas of Australian capital cities may spend more than 90 minutes commuting to work, the data shows that only around two in 10 people around the country face commutes of that length. Mr Shorten is wrong.

column3: Fact check: Does Australia spend more on offshore processing than the UN spends on refugee programs in South East Asia?
column4: Director of the Human Rights Law Centre Daniel Webb claims Australia is currently spending more than five times the United Nations refugee agency's entire budget for all of South East Asia on offshore processing of asylum seekers.
column17: Daniel Webb, director of the Human Rights Law Centre, says Australia is currently spending "more than five times the United Nations refugee agency's entire budget for all of South East Asia" on offshore processing of asylum seekers.
column18: Although difficult to pinpoint a final figure, current spending for the 2014-15 financial year based on Senate estimates is comfortably over $1 billion, while the UN's budget for the South East Asia region is $US157 million in 2015. Mr Webb's claim checks out.

column3: Fact or fiction: A mother and father is better than same-sex parents
column4: An argument often used by religious groups against legalising same-sex marriage is that it will have a negative impact on children's wellbeing.

column3: Fact check: Are staff working in detention centres protected by whistleblower laws if they speak out?
column4: Labor's Immigration spokesman Richard Marles claims whistleblower protection, which applies across the public service, also applies to workers at the Manus and Nauru detention centres.
column17: Labor's Richard Marles says whistleblower protection, which applies across the public service, also applies to workers at the Manus and Nauru detention centres.
column18: Whistleblower laws apply to workers in offshore detention centres who come across wrongdoing, but questions remain as to how well these laws protect those workers if they choose to speak to the media.  Mr Marles's claim is correct, but there's more to the story.

column3: Fact check: Do Australians pay less GST than people in other OECD nations?
column4: New South Wales Premier Mike Baird claims the average rate of GST across OECD nations is around 20 per cent, and Australia's GST is "right down the bottom"
column17: New South Wales Premier Mike Baird says the average rate of GST across OECD nations is around 20 per cent, and Australia's GST is "right down the bottom".
column18: According to 2015 OECD data, the average rate of GST in OECD countries is 19.2 per cent. Only three OECD countries having lower GST tax rates than Australia. Overall Australia collects approximately 7.5 per cent of GDP from taxes on goods and services. The OECD average is 11 per cent. Mr Baird is correct.

column3: Fact check: Does the China Free Trade Agreement threaten Australian jobs?
column4: Unions claim the free trade agreement between Australia and China "allows Chinese companies to bring in their own workforce for projects over $150 million and removes the requirement that jobs be offered to local workers first".
column17: Unions say the China-Australia Free Trade Agreement "allows Chinese companies to bring in their own workforce for projects over $150 million and removes the requirement that jobs be offered to local workers first".
column18: The agreement allows the Immigration Department to decide that jobs should be offered to local workers before it issues visas to overseas workers, but it does not require this to happen. The ACTU's claim checks out.

column3: Fact check: Is Australia the sunniest continent on Earth?
column4: The ALP has called for a massive increase in renewable energy by 2030, with Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claiming Australia has more solar coverage than any other continent.
column17: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten says Australia has more solar coverage than any other continent.
column18: Experts say the data shows Africa and Australia have the same global horizontal radiation - one measure of solar coverage, and Australia has more direct normal irradiance - the other measure - than any other continent. Mr Shorten's claim Australia has more solar coverage than other continents checks out.

column3: Fact check: Is the proposed Shenhua Watermark coal mine located in the middle of Australia's best agricultural land?
column4: Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce says the Shenhua Watermark coal mine on the Liverpool Plains in northern New South Wales will be located in the middle of Australia's best agricultural land.
column17: Barnaby Joyce says the Shenhua coal mine on the Liverpool Plains will be located in the middle of Australia's best agricultural land. He said: "There might be other land that is as good, but there's none better."
column18: Mr Joyce is correct to say the mine will be located in the middle of the plains. Whilst experts say comparing different types of agricultural land is like comparing apples and oranges, they said that the land in the Liverpool Plains is among the best in Australia for broadacre agriculture. Mr Joyce's claim is close to the mark.

column3: Fact Check: Have electricity prices dropped $550 since the carbon tax was abolished?
column4: Treasurer Joe Hockey claims that Treasury documents show "electricity prices have come down $550 per household as a result of us abolishing the carbon tax".
column17: Treasurer Joe Hockey says that Treasury documents show "that electricity prices have come down $550 per household as a result of us abolishing the carbon tax".
column18: The documents, dated up to February 2015, contain predictions that household savings - not electricity savings - will be $550 over 2014-15. The ACCC's most recent estimates for annual savings on electricity bills - which are based on the actual savings passed on by companies to consumers - range between $100 and $200 depending on which state or territory the household is located. Mr Hockey's claim is wrong.

column3: Fact check: Does Australia have one of the 'highest loss of species anywhere in the world'?
column4: Greens leader Richard Di Natale says it is important that endangered species be considered by the Federal Courts when approving coal mining projects, claiming Australia has "one of the highest loss of species anywhere in the world".
column17: Greens Leader Richard Di Natale says Australia has "one of the highest loss of species anywhere in the world".
column18: When comparing places on the IUCN Red List, Australia is in the top five for extinction of animals and plant species, and the top 10 for endangered and threatened species. Senator Di Natale's claim is correct.

column3: Fact check: Why Tony Abbott's claims on emissions targets get mixed verdicts
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims Australia’s per capita emissions target for 2030 are “the best in the developed world”.

column3: Fact check: Is there 'no or very little' link between alcohol advertising and underage drinking?
column4: Amid concerns that children are exposed to thousands of alcohol advertisements during sport broadcasts, the Brewers Association claims there is no link or very little link between alcohol advertising and alcohol misuse, including underage drinking.
column17: The chief executive of the Brewers Association, Denita Wawn, says there is no or very little link between alcohol advertising and alcohol misuse, including underage drinking.
column18: While more research about the relationship between alcohol advertising and drinking habits is needed, experts say the weight of evidence clearly shows a significant risk attached to advertising exposure and youth drinking. Mrs Wawn's claim there is no or very little causation between alcohol advertising and alcohol misuse, including underage drinking, doesn't check out.

column3: Fact check: Is it a crime to attack a royal commissioner?
column4: Prime Minister Tony Abbott has defended Dyson Heydon's integrity and warned Labor MPs that it is a criminal offence to criticise a royal commissioner.
column17: Tony Abbott says it is a criminal offence to attack a royal commissioner.
column18: There is a criminal offence for "insulting" a royal commissioner but experts say the provision is likely to be unconstitutional because it impinges on the right to comment on political matters. Mr Abbott's claim is oversimplified.

column3: Fact check: Is it illegal for Australia to bomb Islamic State in Syria?
column4: Independent federal MP Andrew Wilkie claims "it is illegal for Australia to bomb in Syria" because governments can't bomb a sovereign state which poses no threat to other countries.
column17: Independent federal MP Andrew Wilkie says that "it is illegal for Australia to bomb in Syria" because governments can't bomb a sovereign state which poses no threat to other countries.
column18: Experts say the UN Charter has been interpreted as only allowing states to attack other states but international law is evolving towards permitting attacks against non-states and it is not possible to say the action is legal or illegal. Mr Wilkie's claim is doubtful.

column3: Fact check: Do big companies run by a Peter, a Michael, a David or an Andrew outnumber those run by women four to one?
column4: Sex Discrimination Commissioner Elizabeth Broderick said: "There are fewer big Australian companies that are run by women than by men named Peter."
column17: Sex Discrimination Commissioner Elizabeth Broderick says fewer big Australian companies are run by women than by men named Peter and companies run by men named Peter, Michael, David or Andrew outnumber those run by women four to one.
column18: When Ms Broderick made her claim, there were 11 companies in the S&P/ASX 200 index with a female chief executive and 14 with a man named Peter. Forty-nine companies had a chief executive named Peter, Michael, David or Andrew, outnumbering those with a woman by four to one. When the chairmen are added, there were 23 companies with a woman in one of the top two jobs and 29 with a man named Peter. Seventy-six companies had a man named Peter, Michael, David or Andrew in one of the top two jobs, outnumbering those with a woman by three to one. Ms Broderick's claim is close to the mark.

column3: Fact check: Will Australia's refugee intake in 2015-16 be the highest since WWII?
column4: The Government has responded to the unfolding humanitarian crisis in the Middle East by announcing Australia will take an additional 12,000 refugees fleeing Syria and Iraq in 2015-16, which Foreign Minister Julie Bishop claims amounts to the single largest refugee intake since World War II.
column17: Foreign Minister Julie Bishop claims that Australia's refugee intake in 2015-16, as a result of taking 12,000 people from Syria and Iraq, will be the single largest since World War II.
column18: Department of Immigration data shows that this year's intake will be Australia's largest since those sparked by World War II. Ms Bishop is correct.

column3: Fact check: Do many more people die by suicide than in road accidents?
column4: Lifeline Australia chairman John Brogden claims Australia's road toll has decreased significantly to less than half the number of deaths by suicide.
column17: Lifeline Australia chairman John Brogden recently called for suicide to be declared a national emergency, claiming Australia's road toll has decreased significantly to less than half the number of deaths by suicide, which he says have increased.
column18: Mr Brogden can say that road deaths have declined sharply in the last decade and are half the number of suicides, but the data about the extent of the increase in suicides over the same period is unreliable. His claim is in the ballpark.

column3: Fact check: Do eight out of 10 taxpayers pay for Australia's social services bill?
column4: Treasurer Scott Morrison claims Australia has a spending problem, not a revenue problem.
column17: Treasurer Scott Morrison says that there are "eight in 10 income taxpayers required to go to work every day to pay for the $154 billion social services bill".
column18: In 2015, tax paid by fewer than the top five out of 10 income taxpayers is sufficient to fund Australia's social services bill. Furthermore, social services are paid from the consolidated revenue fund, which comprises all taxes raised by the Federal Government, with personal income tax providing just under half the total. Mr Morrison's claim is misleading.

column3: Fact check: How many students leave higher education with STEM qualifications?
column4: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims 16 per cent of Australian students graduate with STEM qualifications, a figure that is well below the completion rate for students in countries such as Singapore and China.
column17: Federal Opposition Leader Bill Shorten says Australia ranks poorly with comparable countries on collaboration between industry and universities in STEM fields, and that "16 per cent of graduates in Australia finish with STEM qualifications; it's something like 51 or 52 per cent in Singapore and 45 per cent in China".
column18: Mr Shorten appears to have relied on data that is out of date when making the claims, but his claims about Australia's position on collaboration and graduation rates are broadly comparable with current data. Mr Shorten's claim is in the ballpark.

column3: Fact check: Does Uber need the law to change?
column4: The CEO of the Victorian Taxi Association, David Samuel, claims the arrival of Uber has left the established taxi industry the victim of an uneven playing field, with Uber not having to bear the costs that the rest of the industry faces.
column17: CEO of the Victorian Taxi Association, David Samuel, says "there is a set of rules in place and none of those rules inhibit Uber from providing the service they provide, they just don't want to bear the costs that we bear".
column18: Most uberX drivers in Victoria would be able qualify as hire car drivers within the existing legislation, but in practice the significant additional cost is likely to make the uberX business model unviable. Outside of that state, uberX drivers using non-luxury vehicles cannot qualify as hire car drivers even if they are willing to pay the higher charges. There is more to the story.

column3: Fact Check: Was the cost of cutting emissions 100 times greater under Labor?
column4: Environment Minister Greg Hunt claims the Coalition's emissions reduction fund is around 1 per cent of the cost of reducing carbon under the former Labor government's carbon pricing scheme.
column17: Environment Minister Greg Hunt says the Coalition's emissions reduction fund, at $13.95 per tonne of carbon, is around 1 per cent of the cost of reducing carbon under the former Labor government's carbon pricing scheme, which he says cost $1,300 a tonne.
column18: Experts told Fact Check that government revenue raised by the carbon price did not represent the cost of that method of reducing emissions and that comparing the carbon price, which raised government revenue, with the ERF, which is a government expense, didn't make sense because the money raised from the carbon price was distributed back into the economy. Mr Hunt's comparison of the two schemes is untenable.

column3: Fact check: If diabetes were a country how big would it be?
column4: Federal Assistant Minister for Health Ken Wyatt claims diabetes is a growing global issue. Mr Wyatt said "if diabetes was a country it would be the fifth largest country in the world".
column17: Federal Assistant Health Minister Ken Wyatt says that "if diabetes was a country it would be the fifth largest country in the world".
column18: The International Diabetes Federation says there are 208 million people with diagnosed diabetes in the world, which is the size of Brazil, the fifth largest country. However, looking at all people living with diabetes, including those who haven't been diagnosed, would make diabetes the third largest country in the world behind China and India. Mr Wyatt's claim is justified.

column3: Fact check: Christopher Pyne's claims on private schools and religion get mixed verdicts
column4: Minister for Industry, Innovation and Science, Christopher Pyne claims Australia has the highest proportion of non-government schools in the OECD, and almost all of them are religious.
column17: Cabinet minister Christopher Pyne says Australia has the highest proportion of non-government schools in the OECD, and almost all of those schools are religious.
column18: OECD data indicates Australia ranks fourth in the OECD for its proportions of students attending primary and lower secondary schools, and fifth for upper secondary schools. Data from the ABS and the Independent Schools Council of Australia suggest 94 per cent of Australian private schools are religious. No, Australia does not have the highest proportion of non-government schools in the OECD, but yes, almost all of those schools are religious.

column3: Fact check: Is Nauru virtually a failed state?
column4: Independent federal MP Andrew Wilkie claims the "Republic of Nauru is virtually a failed state".
column17: Independent federal MP Andrew Wilkie says that the "Republic of Nauru is virtually a failed state".
column18: Whilst there are serious concerns about the sustainability of Nauru's economic growth and the commitment of the government to human rights protections and the rule of law, it is clear that Nauru does have a government that is in control and its economy is functioning. Mr Wilkie's claim is exaggerated.

column3: Fact check: Comparing Labor and the Coalition's records on foreign aid
column4: Opposition foreign affairs spokeswoman Tanya Plibersek announced Labor would restore $40 million to Australia's aid budget if re-elected and denies Labor also cut the aid budget when in government.
column17: Opposition foreign affairs spokeswoman Tanya Plibersek says that Labor doubled the foreign aid budget when it was in government, and that "this Government has cut $11.3 billion, it's now about 22 cents in every $100 we spend, it's going down to 17 cents".
column18: While Labor did substantially increase foreign aid spending during six years of government, it was by 80 per cent, not 100 per cent, or double. The Coalition's actual cuts, where foreign aid spending has fallen below the level Labor funded, are around $1.1 billion to date. Australia's foreign aid will fall to 17 cents per $100, but not for nearly 10 years, assuming the current policy is maintained. Ms Plibersek's claim is overblown.

column3: Fact check: Are young Indigenous men more likely to end up in jail than university?
column4: Promising to set targets to close the gap between Indigenous and non-Indigenous people in the justice system, Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims a young Aboriginal man of 18 is more likely to end up in jail than university.

column3: Fact check: Was superannuation designed to get people off the pension?
column4: Assistant Treasurer Kelly O'Dwyer claims Australia's superannuation system "was set up to be an alternative to the aged pension so that people didn't have to rely upon the aged pension or even the part pension".
column17: Assistant Treasurer Kelly O'Dwyer says that Australia's superannuation system "was set up to be an alternative to the aged pension so that people didn't have to rely upon the aged pension or even the part pension".
column18: Key figures in the introduction of compulsory super in Australia say it was introduced for a number of reasons, including a desire to relieve pressure on the social security system as the population ages. But the governments of the day did not sell the policy as a way to get people off the pension and instead said that most people would still get at least a part pension. Ms O'Dwyer is ill-informed.

column3: Fact check: Comparing Australia's income tax take with other OECD countries
column4: Treasurer Scott Morrison claims Australia relies more on income tax (personal and company) than any other country in the OECD except Denmark.
column17: Scott Morrison claims that Australia relies more on income tax than any other OECD country except Denmark.
column18: OECD data shows that Australia does derive a higher proportion of its total tax from personal and corporate income tax than any other country except Denmark. But when all direct taxes, including social security contributions, are included, Australia's reliance on income tax is almost the same as the OECD average. Mr Morrison's claim is not the full story.

column3: Fact check: How do Australia's carbon emissions targets compare?
column4: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims the Government's emissions reduction target of 26 to 28 per cent of 2005 levels by 2030 are comparable to other "similarly situated" countries.
column17: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull says that Australia's carbon emissions reduction targets were comparable to "similarly situated" countries.
column18: The published emissions reduction commitments show that Australia's targets are comparable to most other OECD countries, particularly our major trading partners. However, experts told Fact Check that comparing emissions reductions between countries was very subjective. Mr Turnbull's claim is arguable.

column3: Fact check: Do the Nationals represent Australia's poorest electorates?
column4: Deputy Nationals Leader Barnaby Joyce claims his party's constituents are Australia's poorest.

column3: Fact check: Does Australia export cleaner coal than many other countries?
column4: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims Australia's coal is "by and large" cleaner than coal from other countries.
column17: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull says Australia exports "by and large" cleaner coal than other countries.
column18: Experts say Australian export coal is of a higher quality on average compared with other countries, meaning less is needed to generate the same amount of energy. This leads to lower carbon emissions by weight compared with coal from other countries. Mr Turnbull's claim checks out.

column3: Fact check: Is Australia's emissions reduction target second only to Brazil's?
column4: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims Australia's emissions reduction target of 26 to 28 per cent of 2005 levels by 2030 is "second only to the emission cuts offered by Brazil" when measured on a per capita basis.
column17: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull says that Australia's emissions reduction target of 26 to 28 per cent of 2005 levels by 2030 is "second only to the emission cuts offered by Brazil" when measured on a per capita basis.
column18: Australia's per capita reductions for 2030 will be 50 to 52 per cent lower than 2005 levels, which is smaller than the 53 per cent per capita reduction Brazil will make over the same time period, but the per capita cuts of Norway, at 57 per cent, and Switzerland, at 60 per cent, are even higher than both Brazil and Australia. Mr Turnbull is incorrect.

column3: Fact check: Is Australia's military contribution to the fight against Islamic State the second largest?
column4: Foreign Minister Julie Bishop claims Australia's contribution to the training mission in Iraq of 380 personnel is the second largest after the US, but there is more in the theatre than just training personnel.

column3: Fact Check: Are smart drum lines just a PR exercise?
column4: Humane Society International's Michael Kennedy, claims  a test of smart drums to protect swimmers from sharks in NSW is a PR exercise that will threaten other wildlife rather than make the beach safer.

column3: Fact check: Can a poker machine manufacturer use the TPP to challenge changes to gambling laws?
column4: Independent Senator Nick Xenophon claims the proposed Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement could allow overseas poker machine manufacturers to successfully sue the Government for passing anti-gambling laws.

column3: Fact check: Do the world's 62 richest people hold the same wealth as the poorest 50 per cent?
column4: Oxfam Australia CEO Helen Szoke claims the inequality gap between the rich and poor is widening faster than previously thought.

column3: Fact check: Are 2.5 million Australians in poverty and are one quarter of them children?
column4: Labor Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims millions of Australians, more than 600,000 of them kids, are living below the poverty line. But what do the numbers show?

column3: Fact check: Are 30,000 women and 100,000 men sleeping rough on the streets of Australia?
column4: Former army chief and Australian of the Year David Morrison claims there are more Australians sleeping rough than there are soldiers in the Regular Army.

column3: Fact check: Were 301,000 jobs created in 2015?
column4: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims the Coalition Government has created more than 300,000 new jobs in a single year.

column3: Fact Check: Has the number of children in detention dropped from 2,000 to about 75 under the Coalition?
column4: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims that, since the Coalition came to power three years ago, more than 95 per cent of kids have been removed from immigration detention.

column3: Fact Check: Is Labor's schools policy fully funded?
column4: Shadow Treasurer Chris Bowen claims that Labor's decade-long schools policy, "your child, our future", is fully funded through future budget savings.

column3: Fact check: Are Indigenous children 10 times more likely than non-Indigenous children to be living out of home?
column4: Greens Senator Sarah Hanson-Young claims that, compared to non-Indigenous children, Indigenous kids are far more likely to be living in formal out-of-home care.

column3: Fact check: Do most negative gearers earn a modest income?

column3: Fact check: Did the budget take from working mums and give tax cuts to millionaires?

column3: Fact check: Do two-thirds of negative gearers earn under $80,000?

column3: Fact check: Did the Government triple the deficit and is debt $100b higher?
column4: Labor Opposition Senate Leader Penny Wong claims the Government has tripled the budget deficit in two years, and increased net debt by $100 billion since coming to office.

column3: Fact check: Has the Government cut billions out of public hospitals?

column3: Fact check: Can ASIC do the same job as a financial industry royal commission?
column4: Labor promises to hold a royal commision into "misconduct in the banking and financial services industry". But Treasurer Scott Morrison claims there is nothing that ASIC can't do that a royal commission can do.

column3: Fact check: Is government spending today higher than it was in the GFC?
column4: Labor frontbencher Anthony Albanese claims spending is higher as a proportion of GDP in 2016 than it was during the global financial crisis.

column3: Fact check: Are there 'over a million 457s' in Australia?
column4: Independent Senator Jacqui Lambie claims 457 visas are partly responsible for a lack of employment opportunities in Australia, with more than a million such visas issued.

column3: Fact check: Do carbon emissions always rise under the Coalition?
column4: On its Facebook page, NSW Labor claims emissions always go up under the Liberals.

column3: Fact check: Would a vote among under 30s possibly deliver a Greens PM?
column4: Greens Leader Richard Di Natale claims identity politics is breaking down and that a vote among people under the age of 30 could deliver a Greens prime minister.

column3: Fact check: Do the Greens want Sydney to be without an airport?
column4: Labor spokesman for infrastructure and transport Anthony Albanese claims the Greens would close Kingsford Smith Airport and oppose Badgerys Creek airport, leaving Sydney with no airport at all.

column3: Fact check: Was Labor responsible for 'a record deficit'?
column4: Finance Minister Mathias Cormann claims Labor inherited a $20 billion surplus when it came into office in 2007 and then turned it into a record deficit.

column3: Fact check: Is wages growth now the lowest since records began?
column4: Labor's 10-year plan for the economy, released a month before the election, claims wages growth in 2016 is the lowest it has been since records began.

column3: Fact check: Has Australia's internet speed dropped from 30th to 60th in the world under the Coalition?
column4: Opposition communications spokesman Jason Clare claims Australia's global rank for internet speeds has fallen significantly under the Coalition.

column3: Fact check: Is Labor's economic plan the most comprehensive in living memory?
column4: Shadow treasurer Chris Bowen claimed Labor's 10-year plan for Australia's economy was the most comprehensive economic plan an opposition had released in living memory.

column3: Fact check: Why Peter Dutton's claims on the Coalition's record on refugees get mixed verdicts
column4: Immigration and Border Protection Minister Peter Dutton claims that he moved every child out of detention, brought record numbers of refugees in by plane and that nobody drowned at sea under Operation Sovereign Borders.

column3: Fact check: Did Labor previously make the same arguments as the Government on company tax?
column4: Labor says the Government's proposed program of business tax cuts is a massive cut to multinationals. But Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims Labor's support for corporate tax cuts in the past relied on the very same arguments that his government is now making.

column3: Fact check: Has the Government cut $22 billion from schools?
column4: Labor's education spokeswoman Tanya Plibersek says $22 billion worth of cuts to school funding over the next 10 years means the cuts would affect schools in the country and the city, including those in battling postcodes.

column3: Fact check: Did the Liberal Party lose a million votes last election?
column4: Senator for South Australia Cory Bernardi sought to justify his defection from the Liberal Party by claiming the party's support at the last election had dropped by 1 million votes.

column4: Opposition leader Bill Shorten claims Malcolm Turnbull has announced a tax cut for millionaires and multinationals and tax hike for everyone else.

column3: Fact check: Is the new bank levy similar to levies common right around the developed world, Europe in particular?

column3: Fact Check: Is Pauline Hanson correct about a difference between a bank levy and bank tax?
column4: The controversial bank levy is tax deductible: the banks will be able to claim the amount of bank levy paid as a business expense, which will reduce the amount of corporate tax they have to pay on their profits.

column3: Fact check: Do Australian taxpayers subsidise over half the cost of each student's higher education?
column4: Treasurer Scott Morrison asks students to pay more of their own education costs, while claiming taxpayers subsidise more than half the cost of every student's higher education.

column3: Fact check: Can you criticise the conduct of the courts or of a judge?

column3: Fact check: Will the Government's new citizenship test demand a university-level standard of English?
column4: Tony Burke, the Opposition spokesman for citizenship and multicultural Australia, claims a new language test proposed by the Government would demand the same level of English proficiency that is required for university admission — a standard too stringent for some new migrants.

column3: Fact check: Has trachoma among Indigenous kids fallen from 20pc to 4pc?
column4: Former prime minister Kevin Rudd claims trachoma among Indigenous young people has declined since his National Apology to the Stolen Generations in 2008.

column3: Fact check: Have 700,000 of the poorest-paid people received an effective pay cut?

column4: The school funding debate has raised rival claims over whether the Turnbull Government's reforms are "sector-blind".

column4: It is cheaper to fly internationally than to an important regional centre like Alice Springs, claims Dale McIver of Tourism Central Australia.

column4: While Australian women's educational attainment has steadily increased over the past two decades, the gender pay gap has been "in neutral for 20 years", says Shadow treasurer Chris Bowen.

column3: Fact check: Do more people die in Australia than Sweden due to poorly heated homes?
column4: Liberal MP Craig Kelly claims that poorly heated homes cause more deaths in Australia than in Sweden, despite our milder winters.

column3: Fact check: Does the data show that income inequality has fallen?
column4: Treasurer Scott Morrison claims data shows that according to the accepted international definition of inequality, it has not worsened, it has actually improved.

column4: Opposition climate change and energy spokesman Mark Butler claims a Toyota Corolla bought in the UK is half as polluting as a Toyota Corolla bought in Australia, because Austalia does not have mandatory emission standards.

column3: Fact check: Is Australia the only advanced English-speaking country without same-sex marriage?
column4: Opposition frontbencher Andrew Leigh is among those who claim Australia is the last advanced English-speaking country not to allow same-sex marriage.

column4: Are FODMAPs a type of food that causes digestive problems for up to one in three people?

column4: Shadow attorney-general Mark Dreyfus claims that on the High Court's current interpretation, Nationals Senators Fiona Nash and Matt Canavan, as well as Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce would be ineligible to sit in Parliament.

column3: Fact check: Is Australia's tax to GDP ratio lower now than it was throughout the Howard years?
column4: Top former bureaucrat Michael Keating, who argues Australia should lift taxes to avoid a budget blowout linked to the ageing population, claims the ratio of tax to gross domestic product is lower now than it was under the Howard Government.

column3: Fact Check Zombie: Julie Bishop repeats misleading claim on changing the GST on tampons
column4: Politicians from both sides repeatedly claim the GST on tampons can only be scrapped if all states and territories agree. column4: The University of Queensland's Professor Graeme Orr, claims High Court justices can hold dual citizens but parliamentarians cannot.

column3: Fact check: Is the level of Liberal women in Parliament lower now than it was in 1996?

column3: Fact check: Does the projected increase in revenue from the Government's crackdown on illicit tobacco rely on smokers switching to legal product?

column3: Fact check: Are ABC employees or journalists five times more likely to vote for the Greens than the general population?

column3: Fact check: Could asylum seekers travelling from New Zealand obtain a visa on arrival in Australia?

column3: Fact check: Is sugar consumption down while obesity rates have risen?
